The fundamental justification for a bridge inspection programme lies in the assurance of safety. Timely and economic planning and programming of remedial and preventive maintenance and repair work are dependent upon detailed bridge inspection. Inspection is aimed at identifying and quantifying deterioration, which may be caused by applied loads and factors such as deadload, liveload, wind load and physicalchemical influences exerted by the environment. Inspection is particularly necessary in case of old bridges not designed to modern loading standards. To identify actual and potential sources of trouble at the earliest possible stage. To record systematically and periodically the state of the structure. To impose speed restriction on the bridge if the condition situation warrants the same. To determine and report whether major rehabilitation of the bridge is necessary. Bridges over water are inspected at times of low water, generally after the monsoon. Bridges suspected of having trouble on account of thermal movement should be inspected during temperature extremes. The bridges are inspected starting from foundations and ending with superstructures. The pull-off test is based on the concept that the tensile force required to pull a metal disk, together with a layer of concrete, from the surface to which it is attached, is related to compressive strength of concrete. The objective of this research project has been to carry out an extensive filtering reconditioning of inspection data. The report does not constitute a standard, specification, regulation, product endorsement, or an endorsement of manufacturers. A computer program has been developed to calculate deterioration rates by Markov Chain and Weibull-based approaches. The computer program uses an updateable inspection database and generates quadratic equations of desired orders for deterioration rates. The main outcome of this project is a computer program for the calculation of deterioration rates. The computer program generates deterioration curves in the form of condition ratings versus age. These equations can be fed into the bridge management system such as PONTIS by the NYSDOT. This report describes the development of bridge element deterioration rates using the NYSDOT bridge inspection database using Markov chains and Weibull-based approaches. The outcome of the project will be implemented immediately by the NYS Department of Transportation and will continue to be used for many years in future. A computer program has been developed to generate deterioration curves and equations for bridge elements in New York State. Markov chains and Weibull-based approaches have been incorporated into a computer program that generates deterioration curves for specific bridge elements, based on historical NYSDOT bridge inspection data going back to 1981. Deterioration of bridge elements occurs because of the combined effects of several complex effects. The deterioration of bridge Elements is described in the following sections. The sections are ordered by the type of bridge element. The condition assessment of the bridge infrastructure of New York State NYS is crucial in preparing five and ten-year capital programs for the construction and maintenance of bridges. More than 31 of bridges in the United States are considered deficient. A number of states, including New York, Pennsylvania and Indiana, developed their own BMS. This project is focused on element level deterioration versus overall bridge deterioration curves. Without an effective system to determine deterioration rates, maintenance, repair and rehabilitation MRR decisions will be seriously hampered. In the United States, condition ratings1 are used for standardized reporting of visual inspections of bridges. The New York State Departments ratings use ordinal, integer- values scales that indicate relative health of bridge elements. In accordance with New York State and Federal regulations NYSDOT 1997, components in all spans of the bridge are inspect. The overall Bridge Condition rating is computed by weighted average of the integer element condition ratings and is a function of selected weights. The bridge inspection program at the New York State Department of Transportation started in 1981. NYSDOT maintains an inventory of over 17,000 highway bridges across the state. These bridges are inspected biennially, or more often as necessary. Historical bridge inspection data can be used to develop models that can predict future bridge conditions and life-cycle predictions. The models can be updated and re-calibrated with the availability of new inspection data. Develop criteria to filter out erroneous or incompatible inspection data, classify filtered data according to climate and geographical location. Develop algorithms to calculate deterioration rates for classified bridge elements, major structural components and the overall bridge system. Develop a fully automated computer program based on Windows environment for determining the deterioration rates of individual bridge elements. AASHTO has prescribed a bridge-deterioration model as one of the minimum requirements of any BMS. By definition, a facility deterioration model links a measure of facility condition to a vector of explanatory variables. Explanatory variables, such as age, traffic, and weather, are defined as factors that affect facility deterioration.  models calculate the predicted conditions deterministically by ignoring the random error prediction and have several limitations. i they neglect the uncertainty due to inherent stochasticity of infrastructure deterioration and the existence of unobserved explanatory variables. ii they predict the average condition of a family of facilities regardless of the current condition and the condition history of individual facilities. Stochastic models treat the facility deterioration process as one or more random variables that capture the uncertainty and randomness of this process. Markovian models have been used extensively in modeling the deterioration rates of infrastructure facilities, e.g., pavement prediction model Butt et al 1987. Chase and Gaspar 2000 investigated load capacity of highway bridges with age using Markovian Decision Process. Their study is based on 409,741 bridges in the NBI database and the Hungarian Bridge Databank. Markovian models currently implemented in advanced BMS such as Pontis and BRIDGIT use the first-order Markovian Decision Process. They still suffer from the following limitations i they assume discrete transition time intervals, constant bridge population, and stationary transition probabilities, which are sometimes impractical. The most commonly used approach for the estimation of transition probabilities is the linear regression method Carnahan et al. 1987. Despite several limitations of the Markov process described above, it is the most widely used.  linear regression based approach fails to capture the deterioration process because the change in condition within an inspection period is not explicitly modeled. Madanat and Ibrahim 1995 proposed a solution to these problems by calculating transition probabilities by Poisson regression model or negative binomial model. In order to model deterioration behavior of structures more realistically, several researchers have proposed to combine probabilistic models e.g. Markov chain approach and mechanistic models. For the calculation of deterioration rates using the NYSDOT inspection data, the authors have chosen to use both Markov chains and Weibull based approaches.

NYSDOT provided a database containing B-history bridge history, S-history span history inspection data, and inventory data tables for the calculation of deterioration rates. Extensive data filtering has been done on the inspection data and bridge inventory information provided by NYSDOT. In addition to this, reconditioning of inspection data has been carried out based Most bridges in New York State are only inspected every two years. Inspection ratings for elements during intermediate years between two consecutive inspection cycles are set to values corresponding to those of the proceeding year. If the bridge was built within a few years prior to when the NYSDOT bridge inspection program began in 1981, all ratings from the year built to the year of nonzero rating is set to 7. 2.2. Estimation of the correct age of bridge elements is necessary for the development of realistic 15deterioration curves. In case of bridges with elements reconstructed after the original bridge built date, the year of bridge element reconstruction must be known. Inspection data were analyzed to identify bridge elements with two point improvements in ratings over consecutive inspections. This would indicate significant rehabilitation work. If the rating was a two point improvement to a 7, the element was likely replaced. All data before the improvement were discarded. These element data where not included as we were interested in the development of deterioratio. The above filtering criteria cannot identify elements that were rehabilitated before the NYSDOT bridge inspection started in 1981. Additional rules have been implemented to identify possible rehabilitation in such cases. Extensive algorithms have been developed to identify such situations and to recondition identified data. The two ratings of 6 are likely due to only one inspection cycle, since most bridges are only inspected every two years. The data is modified to be condition rating 5 for 14 years. This modification is designed to minimize the effects of rater subjectivity. NYSDOT maintains an element work history in BHISTORY and SHISTORY databases. Information about element built year can also be derived from these databases. A filter was developed to identify if the condition rating was 7 at element rebuild year. Inclusion of very old bridges in the deterioration rate calculations can introduce serious bias in the results. For example, several elements of bridges built in 1950s are likely to be replaced before the inspection started in 1981. In order to partially address this issue, a limit of maximum number of years in a rating was imposed on the inspection data. These restrictions were imposed on structural decks through a simple filtering logic. Based on these calculations, it was determined that bridge decks can stay up to 35 years in rating 7 and 50 years in ratings 6. The impact of some of the biases introduced because of bridge element reconstruction before the start of bridge inspection in 1981 can be minimized by imposing further restrictions on some elements. These restrictions are described for various elements in the following. Eliminates or modify data based on composite decks not used prior to 1942. If built before 1890, eliminate data for abutment joint type 04 Finger type or joint type 07 Preformed Elastomeric Seals. Eliminate data for abutment joint types 15 to 18 or joint types 29 to joint type 34 i.e., all strip seal joints. If bridge built before 1968 and has weathering steel primary members, then primary member has been rebuilt after 1968. Use of pre-stressed concrete primary member started after 1955. Figure 2-3 shows the deterioration curve for structural deck using unfiltered data. It is observed that the structural deck condition ratings start increasing after the age of 50 years. This is because of bias introduced into the data. Figure 2-4 shows deterioration curves generated by Markov and Weibull approaches. It is observed that the filteringreconditioning has effectively eliminated the effects of bias. Condition ratings beyond the age of 60 years are seen to be decreasing with age. The deterioration processes of bridge elements may depend on factors related to geographic locations, climatic conditions, traffic loads, material type of the bridge, etc. It is advantageous to classify all bridges based on available information so that we can apply the deterioration model on group of bridges with similar characteristic to achieve reasonable and accurate deterioration rates. A cascading algorithm has been developed so that bridges can be classified by considering a combination of any number of factors. A brief description of various factors for classification of bridges is presented in the following.

Deterministic approaches are based on statistical and non-linear regression analysis of data to determine deterioration rates. Some of the common deterministic methods to calculate deterioration rates are i Average T for Transition of States Curves, ii Average of Ratings Curves and iv Ordinary Least Square Approach. In stochastic approaches, bridge element ratings or duration at a particular rating are assumed to be random variables and are modeled by an underlying probability distribution. The ordinary least square approach to can used to obtain condition rating as a function of different factors affecting bridge element deterioration. Bridge deterioration process depends on many factors, such as Average Annual Daily Truck Traffic AADTT, climate, maintenance level, etc. Although deterministic models have been used to calculate deterioration rates, stochastic models are inherently capable of accounting for the uncertainty and randomness factors. We have selected both Markov chains and Weibull-based approach to calculate deterioration rates using NYSDOT bridge inspection data. These two methods have been programmed into a computer program developed for the calculation of deterioration rates. Markovian models address the uncertainty of the deterioration process and account for the current facility condition in predicting the future one. They still suffer from several limitations such as i they assume discrete transition time intervals, constant bridge population, and stationary transition probabilities. The Markov chains process is the most widely used approach for deterioration modeling. For the NYSDOT bridge inspection system, seven bridge condition ratings from 7 to 1 can be defined as seven Markovian states. Without repair or rehabilitation, the bridge condition rating should decrease with increase in bridge age. There is a probability, p , of a bridge element transiting from one ij condition state, say i, to another state, j, between inspections. The probability of state i not transitioning to state j is then 1- p . The lowest rating possible is 1. The deterioration rate at any age can be defined as the slope of the condition rating curve in Eq.4-3. The transition t 0 probability matrix P in E. g 6 34State 2 can be used to estimate condition rating R as a function of time. Non-homogeneity of the continuous deterioration process is captured indirectly through segmentation of bridge elements into age groups. Within each group, Markov Chains are assumed to be homogeneous. A new bridge element is almost always given a condition rating of 7. The transition matrix P in Eq.4-1 is determined using nonlinear programming. The starting state vector Q is used to determine R for 10 to 20 years 10 P,t interval using P matrix for this age group. This process is followed until R is generated for the P,.t entire age range of interest. Data generated by Markov Chains processes using 10-year age groups are used as original data Yt in Eq.4-4 to derive one transition matrix for the age group from 0 to 40 years. Markov chains data generated by this transition matrix will follow the dominant deteriorating behavior during the first 40 years of data. Censoring takes place when the duration at a specific condition level is not completely observed. This happens for the latest condition rating on file or when the condition rating of a bridge element is improved. In Markov Chains, there are only two choices regarding censored observation disregard them or treat them as actual durations. Weibull distribution-based approach can handle censored data by explicitly considering duration dependency in the analysis. International Conference on Retrofitting K-mean clustering algorithm iteratively partitions a set of data points into K groups. The basic algorithm consists of the following steps. Assign each data point into the group whose center is nearest. Re-compute the center of each group. Repeat step 3 and 4 until either no point has been assigned to a new group or reassignment wont decrease the sum of distance. K is the number of clusters we are expecting. We can get an idea as to how many clusters we should expect from other relevant information. In other situations, where we dont know K in advance, we can try a different K. Mistry Carbon Fiber-Reinforced Polymer Reinforcing to Extend the Fatigue Lives of Existing Steel Bridges The authors of this article have published a number of articles on the subject of bridge management. The articles are divided into three sections. The first section is titled "Bridge Management in Transportation Agencies" The German Approach to Bridge Management Current Status and Future Development PETER HAARDT RALPH HOLST Federal Highway Research Institute Germanys road infrastructure grew over centuries to become the arteries and lifelines of our society. There is a strong need for management solutions during the whole service life of a structure. The definition of criteria for evaluation of the relevance of failure mechanisms, including acceptance thresholds, requires the availability of relevant data for management procedure. A high-quality road infrastructure is a fundamental precondition for an industrial society. Road infrastructure is not exclusively technical by nature it also has social, political, and ecological dimensions. As Europe grows economically and culturally closer together, the road infrastructure will come under greater pressure. Life-cycle-oriented road infrastructure management is indispensable in Germany. The federal road network carries the main load of the transit traffic by reason of its central position in Europe. Most state departments of transportation employ a bridge management system BMS. The objective of this study has been to gather information on how bridge management information is used for agency decision making on bridge investments and resource allocation. Bridge management information is used in resource allocation decisions in all transportation agencies that were included in this study. Some agencies apply bridge management techniques that are at the state of the art, but the majority appear to use only a subset of existing BMS capabilities. B ridges are critical and highly visible components of a transportation system. Designing, building, maintaining, repairing, and replacing bridges involve significant investment decisions. Agencies try to get these investments right to minimize life-cycle cost and to provide safe and efficient mobility to transportation system users. This paper summarizes the key findings to date of this study. Bridge management in the United States has advanced considerably in the past 40 years. The National Bridge Inspection Standards NBIS were implemented in the 1970s. Bridge structural deficiency SD and functional obsolescence FO, two ratings that the NBIS defined, became key performance measures. While some revisions to NBIS have occurred, the definition and application of these bridge ratings have remained essentially unchanged for more than 30 years. The SD and SR ratings are somewhat inconsistent with respect to bridge decks. While SD directly reflects a deck condition that is poor or worse, the SR is much less sensitive. Since SR is one of the criteria of project eligibility for federal highway bridge program funding, this inconsistency can create problems. The NBI ratings play a significant role in apportioning federal bridge program funds to states. The NBI is the primary data source for the disbursement of funds through HBRRP Highway Bridge Replacement and Rehabilitation Program. NBI conditionperformance ratings are aggregate measures. This form of bridge management based on NBI data utilizes aggregated information. While the formula is convenient for funds allocation, it is not necessarily sufficient for analysis and needs prediction. Today all state DOTs have a bridge management process. Most also employ some type of automated BMS with an associated database of bridge-related information. This database typically includes NBIS data and ratings, but often incorporates additional, more detailed, or customized data. Pontis is a full-featured BMS in use in more than 40 state DOTs and several other city, county, and international agencies. NBI data are included for annual reporting to FHWA, and additional, custom data defined by the agency are likewise included. 32 Transportation Research Circular E-C128 International Bridge and Structure Management Conference Needs assessment and strategy development estimate and update bridge element deterioration and treatment cost models. develop long- range, network-level policies for both structure preservation and bridge improvement. KUBA is similar to other state-of-the-art management systems but has numerous distinctive characteristics. In its final stage the national road network will comprise about 4,000 b. Major part of the current road structures has already reached an age of 30 years. The purpose of road infrastructure is to ensure fast and safe passage between any two points on the road network. There is an increasing pressure to reduce public funds for transportation infrastructure in general. The goals of users are already stated they are interested in fast, safe, and reliable passage between o The goals of operators are to minimize their expenditures and still maintain traffic capacity. Environmentalist groups aim for a reduction of pollution and of the consumption of nonrenewable resources related to traffic. Business-friendly groups advocate better connections to their businesses. An efficient road network has multiple positive effects on the economy, including reducing transportation costs, enabling the concentration of production facilities, fostering spending, inducing new real estate development projects, etc. It is well known from various statistical indicators that new roads induce an increase in gross domestic product GDP 2. The value generated by road traffic is estimated at CHF 46 billion or about 10 of the GDP. The absolute increase in GDP due to new or improved road links is very difficult to quantify. In infrastructure management, marginal changes in GDP are estimated by monetarily quantifying changes in traffic conditions. The goals of external stakeholders are difficult to quantify monetarily. Assessment models for the user costs or benefits with various levels of sophistication are currently available. Unfavorable changes in traffic conditions can occur either on the supply side, due to natural deterioration, catastrophic events, etc., or on the demand side, e.g., due to traffic increase and load increase.  Preservation and improvement interventions are to be treated separately. Preservation interventions do not induce any user benefit since the level of service before and after the intervention remains unchanged. The purpose of improvement interventions is to reduce user costs, i.e., induce long-term user benefit less congestion, higher speeds, heavier trucks. For road structures on Swiss national roads, the assessment units are structural elements. It is, therefore, necessary to define the elements for each structure prior to first inspection. Elements are primarily classified using a catalogue of element types and so-called construction types. A condition rating describes the type, severity, and extent of damage. Type of damage is, in this context, a synonym for the deterioration process. A scale of five CS was adopted, ranging from 1 good condition to 5 requiring urgent attention. The condition forecast allows defining preservation projects for any given period in the future. The forecast requires a model that simulates the future condition of an element or segment, given the current condition and the likely environmental influences. Markov chains are used for the condition forecast. The deterioration process is modeled by its own, characteristic Markov chain. The transition matrices of the Markov chains are calculated and updated by a statistical analysis of the condition data collected during inspections. Portions of the same element subjected to the same deterioration process may behave differently. An unfavorable influence may also correspond to the presence of multiple deterioration processes or to defects. The effect of the influence indicators is implemented by adding so-called influence matrices to the transition matrices of the Markov chains. A preservation intervention results in a CS improvement, which is represented by transition probabilities reflective of the effectiveness of the intervention. The transition probabilities representing intervention effectiveness are calculated and updated by a statistical analysis of the condition data collected during inspections before and after interventions 5. The results of the optimization reduce the number of element interventions that are to be considered for project generation. In order to explain the optimization procedure, an optimum policy will be assumed according to which, for instance, interventions will be performed in condition state 3. Four intervention policies I2 to I5 and the corresponding expected intervention intervals are presented in Figure 7. The optimum preservation policy is I4 since it minimizes the expected annuities. It can be seen that the optimization procedure is in principle independent of the deterioration function. A project is generated for a structure as soon as one of its elements requires an intervention. The extent of an intervention to be performed and its unit cost are used to calculate the intervention cost. The preservation project generated using the optimum policies for all elements is of particular interest, since it consists of optimum element interventions. The interventions for all elements segments of a structure form a project. The project is characterized by the sum of the costs of interventions. A model has been developed that takes into account the former performance of particular elements to decide whether or not they should undergo interventions. This model will be discussed in more detail in the next chapter. Interventions on certain elements may require traffic restrictions. Examples include the repair or rehabilitation of pavement, a bridge deck, joints, or retaining the walls along a road. Optimization on the project level aims to support the agency in deciding which projects to perform in a planning period. The optimization on the project level is not needed if sufficient funds are available. If, however, the available funds are not sufficient, an optimum set of projects is estimated that fits into the available budget. This problem is known as the knapsack problem. Markov transition probabilities can be regarded as relative frequencies of a large number of observed condition state transitions. For instance, the coefficient p expresses the relative 23 frequency of observed transitions from CS 2 in CS 3. This also means that by the law of large numbers the same relative frequency of transitions can be expected in the future. The Roads Infrastructure Branch of the Provincial Government of the Western Cape is responsible for the management of 6,000 km of paved and 10,000km of unpaved roads. These are basically all rural roads in the province that are not national routes and include approximately 2,300 bridges and major culverts. The PGWC identified the need to acquire a management system to motivate for and allocate limited available funds to rehabilitation projects. MTQ rated the material condition of each bridge component using a scale from 1 to 6 with 6 being an ele- ment in new condition. The numbers on the scale represented a combination of severity of de- fects and their extent. The inspector is required to record the quantity of defects in each of four condition states for each bridge component. These condition states are Excellent or A Good or B Fair or C and Poor or D. Each condition state defines defects on the basis of their severity. MTQ maintains an enterprise Oracle database for its structure inventory and inspection data. Data from the Oracle database are replicated to a Microsoft SQL server database. The replication process offers an added measure of security from unintended database updates. MTQ is moderately decentralized in its decision-making processes. Bridge-level maintenance and repair decisions are made in regional offices from operational funding. Although each of these indices could be used as a performance measure, only the BCI IES is actually used in the analysis. The MTQ bridge con- dition index is based on the same concept as the OBMS BCI. The BCI is a weighted average of the condition state distribution for the various elements that make up a given structure. The element replacement cost is used as the weighting factor. The software was applied to data from several state departments of transportation to compute bridge management system unit costs and action effectiveness measures. Policy-level definitions of maintenance were obtained from AASHTO 1, 2, from FHWA and from nine state transportation agencies. Maintenance actions include routine cleaning and painting as well as repairs and replacements of components. Jorgensens NCHRP report on budgeting for highway maintenance 4 defines maintenance as actions that preserve assets in their as-constructed condition. State DOTS often define maintenance in a similar narrow sense maintenance preserves bridges. Most state DOTs identify maintenance actions in all operations shown in Table 1. Repairs or replacements of components are often classified as maintenance. Larger projects for improvement, bridge reconstruction, and bridge replacement are not maintenance. Some DOTs have separate categories for maintenance of movable spans, of motion equipment, of tunnels, and of other structural assets. Bridge replacement and reconstruction are excluded from maintenance. Improvements to bridges may be maintenance, if projects are small. Budget Budgets in transportation departments identify funds for the maintenance division, for contract maintenance, and for equipment and materials used in maintenance tasks. Bridge replacement or major rehabilitation projects that are eligible for HBRRP funds are not maintenance. Repairs, component replacements, and minor modifications are usually maintenance and may be eligible for HBRRP funds. Bridge replacement and major rehabilitations are not maintenance. The existence, and essential immutability, of each bridge and its makeup are necessary attributes.  maintenance programs consist of two broad categories cyclic work and singular work. A third category, Updating, may be added, though it is not prominent in DOT literature on maintenance. Updating is work to replace obsolete elements such as bridge railings. Bridge maintenance can be defined in terms of policy statements, lists of actions, budget status and the capabilities of maintena. Some DOTs identify maintenance contracts as a separate class, and compute distinct values of average unit costs for pay items in these contracts. U.S. DOTs all recognize maintenance as distinct from construction. Cleaning, painting, and minor repairs are always maintenance. The numbering system allows simple collection of maintenance data by bridge component or by maintenance operation. The conceptual framework for the cost analysis comes in four phases. Economic outputs are a description of work completed in maintenance activities. These include labor, materials, equipment, and contract pay items. Outputs typically use different units of measure than inputs. Typically, the purpose of maintenance activity is to change a deteriorated condition into a better condition. Both cost and quantity of both inputs and outputs are used in the analysis. If any are missing, the analysis can still work without them. The outcome is generally measured by bridge inspection, usually the next regular inspection after the work is done. Costs and quantities can be rolled up i.e., summed to any level of aggregation where it makes sense. Quantities are not necessarily rolled up to the same levels as cost because of the need for compatibility of measurement units. The New York State Department of Transportation maintains an inventory of more than 17,000 highway bridges across the state. Bridge inspectors are required to assign a condition rating for up to 47 structural elements of each bridge. This paper describes the development of bridge element deterioration rates using the NYSDOT bridge inspection database. It is observed that a Weibull-based approach is more reliable for developing bridge deterioration curves. Case studies on deterioration rates of various bridge elements in New York State are presented to demonstrate the two approaches. Condition assessment of the bridge infrastructure is crucial in preparing 5- and 10-year capital programs for the construction and maintenance of bridges. More than 31 of bridges in the United States are considered deficient. Information is extremely valuable in bridge management decision making. The deterioration rates of individual bridge elements are influenced by the combined effects of many complex phenomena e.g. reinforcement corrosion, concrete degradation, creep, shrinkage, cracking, and fatigue. In the absence of mechanistic-based deterioration models that require the quantitative contribution of these complex phenomena, bridge inspection data may be used to estimate future rehabilitation Bridge elements deteriorate over time and their conditions do not improve without some type of intervention. Better understanding of these issues is essential for developing and implementing an effective bridge management program. For example, a bridge element that was at condition rating 5 for 6 years and then went to condition rating 6 for 2 years was recorded as having been at condition rated 5 for 14 years. Bridge deterioration is a stochastic process that depends on many factors, such as average annual daily truck traffic AADTT, climate, and maintenance level. This pre-analysis filtering was crucial in arriving at the most accurate deterioration information. This paper presents a comparative study of deterioration rates calculated by Markov chains and Weibull-based distributions using NYSDOT bridge inspection data. Markovian models are the most common stochastic techniques and have been used extensively in modeling deterioration rates. Markovian models address the uncertainty of the deterioration process and account for the current facility condition in predicting the future. IR thermography, the technology this study focuses on, has gained increasing use in many industries in recent years due to the advancement of imaging technology. IR cameras infer the temperature of a material by measuring the electromagnetic radiation emitted from the surface. All materials emit radiation in the IR range when their temperature is above absolute zero. However, IR thermography has some limitations, such as the cameras inability to determine the depth of the features imaged. Emissivity of a material is the characteristic rate of thermal radiation, relative to a black body. For concrete, emissivity values are typically between 0.92 and 0.97. However, there are many other factors that influence the IR image produced. The thermal gradient created by environmental conditions is relatively small. Direct sunlight solar loading can produce a significant thermal gradient by heating the surface of the structure through radiant heating. Wind can mitigate this effect by drawing away heat through convective cooling. The humidity of the air itself will also affect the convective properties. A large test block was constructed as shown in Figure 1. Styrofoam targets of known thickness, area, location, and depth were embedded in the concrete. Data for variables such as ambient temperature, solar loading, wind speed, humidity, and rainfall were collected and stored by a stand-alone computer system. The IR image displays a two-dimensional temperature representation of the entire face of the block. Temperature differentials thermal gradients were measured by the thermocouples. Thermal contrasts were taken between the surface area directly above the targets and the surface areas directly above sound concrete. Tilt sensors have been proposed and are currently utilized in systems intended to monitor short-term events. These systems frequently include a limited number of tilt sensors, due to cost and other 238Washer, Masterson, Philipps, and Fuchs 239 considerations. The system is being developed to measure both changes in rotation tilt as well as vertical displacement of a pier. The sensors are deployed in a high-density array, such that multiple-sensor outputs can be integrated to eliminate erroneous readings. The system being developed employs electrolytic tilt sensors for monitoring the tilt of a bridge pier and structural displacements. Electrolytic sensors were selected over a microelectro- mechanical systems-based technology due to their greater stability and precision. Lab testing has been conducted using a custom-designed 32-channel data acquisition system developed by Fuchs Consulting, Inc. The system supplies the power to the tilt sensors, logs the output from the sensors at a specified rate, provides temperature measurements, and offers a computer interface for analyzing data. A test bridge has been designed and constructed on which the sensors can be mounted. The project involved characterizing the electrolytic tilt sensors. Testing was completed to calibrate the sensors as well as determine the sensor noise, warm-up periods, temperature effects, and resolution. The voltage output was recorded using the data acquisition system. The calibration factors for electrolytic tilt sensors vary with temperature due to the changing viscosity of the fluid within the sensor. The temperature compensation factor accounts for the change in calibration factor as the temperature varies. In order to verify this factor, a test was completed in which the rotary stage was placed in a temperature chamber. The minimum resolution of the system was found to be no more than 28 arcseconds 0.0077. The nominal temperature compensation factor is acceptable for use in postprocessing. Other tests have also been run in order to characterize the sensors. Among these were tests to evaluate drift and identify noise levels. Algorithms under development to achieve the following: initial filtration, calibration, and temperature compensation, movement computation, determination of sensor consistency, sensor correlation, and critical movement identification. The use of multiple sensors allows one to achieve measurement redundancy. The initial filter has been developed to address errant readings that are consistent among all of the channels. Errant data points that occur in individual channels are addressed in algorithms to test sensor consistency within the sensor array. The filter was developed by utilizing the 3 Sigma Edit Rule.  filter only considers then nearest 48 points when computing the median and median absolute deviation from the median. Detected outliers are replaced in the data set using a median value from nearby points. This method was chosen over replacement with an average or neighboring point in order to account for situations when the data vary greatly or when two consecutive points are deemed outliers.  filter has been shown to detect upwards of 99 of the noise spikes. It is designed to error on the side of false positive readings rather than leaving noise spikes undetected. The noise spikes are eliminated, thus resulting in no inaccurate movement calculations in future postprocessing. The system is sensitive to both instant and gradual tilts. Algorithms have been completed to assess tilt data over 1 h, 12 h, 24 h, 7 days, 28 days, and 90 days. In order to determine the magnitude and direction of pier movements, the programmed algorithms compute the change in tilt over a set time integral using vector comparison. To determine the movement over a set time period, a normal vector is compared to that from the end of the time period. The angle between the two normal vectors is computed based on Equation 2 below. The resulting theta is the magnitude of the change in tilt over that time period in degrees. The system is currently setup such that Sensors 2, 3, and 4 form an array on one side of the pier, while Sensors 5, 6, and 7 form anarray on the opposite side. The sensors are configured in this way so that each side of. the pier has three sensors in order to achieve sensor redundancy. The algorithms first check for errant readings in each sensor individually. Once each sensor is checked individually, sets of sensors are considered. Within each set, an average movement is determined. Each sensors tilt movement is then compared with that average. If any movement varies more than a set threshold from that average, a sensor inconsistency exists. The output furthest from the average belongs to the inconsistent sensor. Figure 9 contains direct output from MATLAB in which one sensor in a set is inconsistent. If the sensors are found to be inconsistent for a certain percentage of the data, a message is sent to the user stating that the sensors in the set are inconsistent and further review is necessary. The algorithms detect that irregularity and a message is given to the user reporting that Sensor 4 is inconsistent for a 1-day period and will be disregarded in further processing. Once all inconsistencies are identified, the remaining sensors in the array are averaged in order to determine one value for the movement of the array. This process is completed for each array. The system is designed with two sensor arrays, one on each side of the pier. In order to ensure consistency between the sets, a method is used in which the difference between the two sides outputs is computed and compared to a predetermined threshold. Once the sets are shown to be consistent with one another, they are combined to determine an overall movement. The program will record movements computed over six different time integrals. The directions from each set are translated to a universal coordinate system and averaged. An overall direction of the tilt of the pier is recorded for each time step as well as the magnitude of that movement. The FHWA uses the National Bridge Investment Analysis System NBIAS to develop its estimates of bridge investment needs for the CP Report. The system predicts the structural elements, including the quantity and condition of each element, for each bridge in the NBI. Once a bridge inventory has been established, the system uses a modeling approach originally adapted from the Pontis Bridge Management System When performing an analysis, the system executes a series of simulations with different annual budgets. Default deterioration models have been developed for each of the nine climate zones through a separate effort. Functional improvements may be triggered either through a functional improvement policy matrix or by any functional issue that results in a deduction in the sufficiency rating.  functional improvements are considered needs if the benefit of making an improvement over a specified analysis period exceeds the improvement cost. Replacement of a bridge may be triggered because replacement is the most cost-effective means to address a preservation or functional improvement need. Engineering rules may be specified based on bridge age, health index, sufficiency rating. FHWA reports on the condition of the bridge network, and on investment needs for bridges, in the biannual Conditions and Performance CP Report. The FHWA uses the computer model National Bridge Investment Analysis System NBIAS to perform its analysis of bridge investment needs. NBIAS requires only the National Bridge Inventory NBI data reported annually to FHWA by each state. Pontis requires element-level data for its modeling. NBIAS has a number of features to support network-level analyses. NBIAS models preservation and functional improvement needs for each bridge in a network. The system uses data on current conditions to predict conditions over time and determine the optimal allocation of resources. This section describes the NBIAS modeling approach. Robert and Gurenich 299 The motivation for the screening procedure is that once a bridge is imported into the system it is assumed that the bridge should be maintained in a state of good repair. If the disbenefit of removing a bridge from service to the cost of replacing the bridge. is less than the replacement cost by a specified factor, the bridge is screened from further analysis. If this parameter is missing or 0, then the default value of 1 is used. NBI data have been imported into the NBIAS database. The system uses a set of models called synthesis, quantity, and condition SQC models. SQC models evaluate information about a bridge from the bridges NBI record, and estimate or synthesize which structural elements would exist based on a mix of engineering and stochastic rules. Once the likely elements are identified, the quantity of the element that one would expect to find on a bridge is estimated. NBIAS models only the AASHTO Commonly Recognized CoRe elements 7. The objective of the preservation models is to find the optimal preservation policy for each bridge element. Delaying a recommended action under optimal policy is costly in the long run. In NBIAS the preservation decision-making process is treated as a Markov decision problem MDP. The net benefit of taking the recommended action is calculated as the difference in the life-cycle cost of the element if action is deferred for 1 year and if the optimal action is taken. NBIAS applies two sets of business rules a functional improvement policy and a set of rules derived from the process of calculating sufficiency rating and structural deficiency. The user may choose to use one or both sets of rules. The second set of business rules is unique to NBIAS. Any functional issue that results in a deduction in sufficiency rating, or that. results in classification of a bridge as SD or FO, triggers a potential need. The following conditions cause identification of a potential widening need. Deck geometry rating NBI Item 68 is less than 6 Underclearances rating N BI Item 69 is less. than 6 as A potential bridge strengthening need is identified if the inventory rating NBI Item 66 is less than 32.4 metric tons. Once a potential need has been identified, the next step is to determine whether it is feasible to perform the improvement on the bridge. The feasibility of the potential improvement is also driven by a set of business rules. NBIAS replacement rules are conceptually similar to rules defined in Pontis 10. The replacement rules in NBIAS differ in that they may be used to trigger only one action, replacement. The next step in the process is to identify the cost of the potential improvement. NBIAS supports two different models for calculation of functional improvement benefits. Raising and strengthening needs are evaluation based NBIAS uses user cost parameters e.g. value of time, vehicle operating costs, crash costs adapted from the HERS model parameters. Once the costs and benefits of a potential functional improvement need have been calculated, NBIAS evaluates whether the bridge is still a candidate for improvement. If R is greater than or equal to the specified threshold, the project becomes a candidate for consideration in the program simulation. Once a project is considered as a candidate, its 1-year benefits and incremental BC ratio are calculated and the candidate competes for funding with other project candidates. NBIAS uses an IBC approach to simulate selection of projects year by year. The objective is to maximize agency and user benefits. NBIAS applies the recommendations of the preservation policy and functional improvement models to the bridge population. NBIAS simulates the effect of project selection on over 200 measures of effectiveness. The system performs one run using a user-specified budget for each analysis period. NBIAS then performs N 1 simulations, in addition to the first simulation described above. When parameterization is done by the cutoff BC ratio, the user specifies the upper and lower limits for the cut-off ratio, and the number of parametric steps. NBIAS then runs the simulation assuming an unlimited budget, and stops allocating funds upon reaching project alternatives with BC ratios below the cutoff. NBIAS predicts 206 measures of effectiveness MOEs. These are grouped into eight categories, as detailed below. Needs measures are reported by the type of work needed to meet the need. In calculating needs, the system sums the cost of all of the work that would be recommended. Most needs are structurallyfunctionally motivated needs. Economically motivated needs, which are exclusively bridge replacements, are reported for the sake of completeness. Work and backlog measures are closely related to needs. They represent the work that would actually be performed given a particular budget level. NBIAS reports two types of benefits obtained and potential. Obtained benefits are the benefits NBIAS simulates as occurring during a program simulation. Potential benefits are benefits that could be obtained if there were no budget constraints or no BC cutoff. FHWA defines condition ratings for deck, superstructure, and substructure conditions in the NBI Coding Guide 3. These ratings, referred to in the system as NBI condition ratings, are based on a scale from 0 to 9. NBIAS calculates the number of bridges and the percentage of deck area classified as SD or FO based on FHWA guidelines. A series of MOEs is used to report the average sufficiency rating. NBIAS offers a comprehensive modeling approach for analyzing highway bridge investment needs at a network level. Despite these features, NBIAS is not a replacement for a BMS. It has no functionality for supporting the bridge inspection process. The system optimizes preservation actions based on the assumption that future decisions will be optimal. The hydraulic vulnerability assessment program starts with an initial screening of the existing bridges to determine which bridges are susceptible to hydraulic-induced failures. The hydraulic assessment HA rates the bridge hydraulic vulnerability as a function of the following 10 categories: River slopeflow velocity, Channel configuration, Existing evidence of scour, Bridge opening capacity, Debrisice accumulation potential. The HA ratings for the 10 categories are then totaled, resulting in a hydraulic vulnerability rating ranging from a maximum of 25 to a minimum of 1. With the HA completed, the focus then shifts to assessing the vulnerability of the bridge foundation BF. As with the HA, the BF vulnerability assessment is a category ranking system. Each of the 12 categories is subdivided into subcategories, with each subcategory being assigned a numerical rating value as a function of the subcategorys contribution to the overall element vulnerability. The structural assessment of the BF is then the maximum AV and PV rating. CS is then employed to assign the various bridges to one of three vulnerability classes. Bridges that cross waterways often have foundation and substructure elements located under water to provide the most economical overall design. The condition of substructure and foundation under water cannot be easily determined. Underwater inspection and management techniques must be undertaken to establish their condition so that unsafe condition can be avoided. Underwater bridge inspections are essential to maintain the safety of the bridges. Specialised equipments and skilled divers are required to carry out a satisfactory under water inspection. The bridge inspector and the diver must be able to act as a team in relaying the proper information. The existing provision on underwater inspection as per para 1107 dis as below. The substructure of the bridges which are normally under water should be inspected by adopting suitable methods which may include engaging of divers and special equipment. It is a good practice to schedule underwater inspection immediately after monsoon. The dive should be timed for the period when the tide is stable for the bridges located in the backwaters. Underwater inspections are of three types a Routine inspection- This is an underwater visual inspection. The basic purpose is to detect obvious damages or problems. This is the maximum interval at which all underwater elements of a bridge, even if it is in sound condition, must be inspected. Any problems identified during the inspection may necessitate going in for Detail Inspection. This inspection should be of Level I. There are three Levels of underwater bridge inspections. Level I is a visual inspection, a feel inspection and a special inspection. Level III is an unscheduled Inspection. This inspection is required to be carried out in the following cases- After unusual floods. After vessel impact unless it is obvious that no damage has occurred. Level I inspection is a visual inspection on entire underwater substructure of the structure to determine obvious major damagesproblems. Level II Detail visual inspection that includes cleaning of areas for closer inspection. Level III Investigation of specific components using Non Destructive Testing. The report of a Level I inspection should comprise of the following Method and extent of investigation. Water depth sounding and scour around piers and abutments. Verification of continuity of the piers in full length. Registration of spalling and corrosion. The marine growth, like algaebarnacles sea grass snails oysters etc. if any, must be cleaned for surface inspection. One or more of the following conditions may dictate the need for a Level II inspection. The cleaning of the substructure components is to be performed in three different water depths. During the inspection, damage or deterioration spalling, corrosion, cracks, etc. or corrosion should be detected and measured. The extent and severity of the damage should be documented. A clear water box and water jet cleaning equipment may be used if necessary. A Level III inspection is a highly detailed inspection of critical components or components where extensive repair or possible replacement is contemplated. The Level III Inspection forms the necessary basis for the detailed assessment of the damage and the preparation of the rehabilitation design. The tests are planned using all available information from the drawings, previous underwater inspections of the bridge, underwater inspections and the knowledge and experience of the persons performing the underwater inspection. On this basis a hypothesis concerning the cause of damage and the condition of the damaged area may be formulated. The scope of Level III inspection can vary substantially by the type and severity of event. Inspection must be sufficient to determine the need for emergency load restriction or closure of bridge to traffic. If measurable damage has occurred, inspections must evaluate section loss, misalignment of members, and loss of foundation support. Significant earthquake bridges also need to be inspected after an earthquake where structural damage is expected. Evidence of deterioration or movement many underwater deficiencies only become apparent above water when the distress extends above the water line or is manifested by lateral movement or settlement. NDT methods which can be used for under water inspection are Ultrasonic Thickness Gauge - Steel. In Scuba diving, the diver is provided with compressed air supply through a Scuba tank, which is strapped to the divers back. The minimum equipments required are scuba, wetdry suit thermal protection, life preserver, weight belt to counter buoyancy, knife for emergency, face mask for breathing, swim fins for navigation, depth gauge to estimate depth, wrist watch, etc. Depending on the site conditions, additional equipments may be resorted to. Mixed air is used for the same situations as normal Scuba diving. It has the advantage of extending the diving time to a great deal. The disadvantage is that it needs more preparation. There is no communication arrangement in standard Scuba equipment. Air is supplied to the diver through umbilical hoses connected to the surface air compressor tank. It requires more equipment than the Scuba diving. Oxygen can be mixed with air Nitrox to extend dive time in shallow water. Trimix or Heliox will make it possible to dive deeper than 36 meters. A number of factors influence the proper underwater inspection method. Depth of water alone should not be the sole criteria in determining whether a bridge can be inspected by skin diving without suit. Still photographs and video records facilitate in-depth documentation of underwater inspection. Still photography shall be done using digital camera of minimum 5.0 Mega pixels with 10x optical zoom. Wide-angle lenses are preferably used where visibility is limited and camera is required to be placed close to the object. Suspended particles often dilute the light reaching the object and can reflect light back into the lens. There are three main problems in turbid water, which limit the viewing performance of an underwater camera. These are - Absorption - Refraction - Reflection. Camera should be capable of taking image at zero Lux with LEDs on. Control the lighting and focussing and communicate with the diver. Reflection is probably the most critical factor for the performance of cameras in turbid water. The suspended particles in the path of illuminating light reflect a portion of the illuminating light directly back into the camera. This backscatter, can often be limiting factor in the use of underwater visual imaging system. The problem of reflection can be minimised by carefully placing the flash away from the axis of the camera and at angle to provide reasonable coverage of the subject. In this arrangement, a very high powered, tight beam spot light beam angle less than 100 is used. The effect of backscatter tends to be much reduced as there is little directly reflected light. The underwater torch should be of minimum capacity of 3 Watt for skin diving and minimum 10 Watt for ScubaSurface area supplied diving. The output of the torch for skin. diving should be 80 Lumen Lm with a burn time of 3 hours and for. other types a minimum of 450 Lumen. Lm. Not suitable for close-up inspection as there will not be enough scatter. Divers can work in current below 1.5 knots with relatively little hindrance. As current increases, special precautions are required. In swifter current, shielding devices and special anchor systems may be required. There is no limit placed on the duration of diver up to 18m depths. Whenever depth of diving exceeds 18m, decompression should be carried out. Divers must also have a safety concern about the build-up of debris near a bridge. The requisite qualification for divers and diving supervisors are given in IS10291 1982, which stipulates that the diver should be at least 18 years of age and should not have any sickness at the time of Diving. The working agency should have its own diving safet. 2 First Aid Standard First Aid Kit Box should be available. For major works requiring engaging Six Divers two Diver-Teams or more preferably a qualified doctor should be present on the Boat. All divers, including equipments, should be covered by Insurance. Underwater inspection should include all pierabutment surfaces between the high waterline and the mud line. The entire pier surface may be divided into suitable number of segments along the perimeter, each covering a spacing of 1 to 1.5 m. This facilitates identification of location of defects. The report includes an evaluation of the assessed conditions and recommendations for further action. The report should provide sufficient technical detail to support the assessment and recommendations. The Level I Level II inspection reports should be sent to sectional Sr.DENDEN for scrutiny and for planning of works. This guide has been used for bridge inspections in Ontario since 1985. The manual underwent significant modifications in the year 2000. A new severity and extent philosophy has been adopted in order to simplify the process.

The previous Material Condition Rating Tables in Part 2 of the manual have been replaced with Condition State Tables. Four Condition States have been defined for bridge elements, namely, Excellent, Good, Fair and Poor. At any given time, areas within a bridge element may be in different Condition States. The new inspection method requires suspected Performance Deficiencies to be identified for each bridge element. Performance deficiencies are chosen from a standard list and are used to flag areas that require the inspector to take some follow-up action. A standard list of maintenance needs has been created.
Ministry of Transportation procedural guidelines have been deleted in an effort to make the manual

The main objectives of Structural Inspections are to maintain structures in a safe condition to protect and prolong the useful life of structures. A detailed visual inspection is an element-by-element close-up visual assessment of material defects, performance deficiencies and maintenance needs of a structure. Close-up is defined as a distance close enough to determine the condition of

The following structures shall be inspected every two years Biennially All bridges, culverts and tunnels with spans of 3 metres or greater. All retaining walls All movable bridges 1-1-2 Ap. This manual describes the procedures for carrying out detailed visual inspections only. For culverts with 3 to 6 metre spans and retaining walls, the inspection interval can be increased to four years. The timeframe of two years and four years refers to calendar years. It is recognized that the level of effort involved in performing a detailed visual inspection will vary depending on structure type and age. The maximum inspection interval and the level of inspection may however vary for certain structures. Some structures may have to be inspected more frequently as directed by the Engineer. Such action can be justified based upon the type of structure, construction details, existing problems or restrictions. More detailed investigations and non-destructive testing techniques are required to identify defects. Inspection procedures detailed in this manual do not apply to the mechanical or electrical parts of movable bridges. The inspection of overhead sign support structures is covered in the Ontario Sign Support Inspection Guidelines. An emergency situation exists when a structural component contributing to overall stability of the structure has failed, or is in imminent danger of failure. In such cases, a detailed visual inspection should be carried out immediately. Typical problems that may cause an emergency situation to develop are Accident or vehicle collision with a structure Spring run-off or major flooding An earthquake Underwater investigation Fatigue investigation Seismic investigation or Structure evaluation. Information on these inspections is contained in Part 3 of this manual. Corrosion ........................................... 1-2-18 2.3.2 Permanent Deformations .............................. 1-1-19 2.4.3 Cracking  Asphalt Pavement. .5.2 Splitting, Spalling and Disintegration .............. 1-2-36 2.5.3 Loss of Mortar and Stones This section describes the defects that are normally found in concrete, steel, wood, masonry, aluminum, asphalt pavements and coatings. Each defect is briefly described and the causes producing it are identified. Severity levels, wherever possible, are established. The following defects commonly occurring in concrete are described - Scaling - Disintegration - Erosion - Corrosion of Reinforcement - Delamination - Spalling - Cracking - Alkali-Aggregate Reaction - Surface Defects. Scaling is the local flaking, or loss of the surface portion of concrete or mortar. Disintegration is the physical deterioration or breaking down of the concrete into small fragments or particles. Disintegration may be caused by de-icing chemicals, sulphates, chlorides or by frost action. Erosion is the deterioration of concrete brought about by water-borne sand and gravel particles scrubbing against concrete surfaces. Similar, damage may be caused by flowing ice. Severe erosion of a concrete footing is shown in Figure 2.2.3. Corrosion is the deterioration of reinforcement by electrolysis. In the initial stages, corrosion may appear as a rust-stain on the concrete surface. The surface concrete above the reinforcement cracks, delaminates and spalls off exposing heavily rusted reinforcement. Delamination is defined as a discontinuity of the surface concrete which is substantially separated but not completely detached from concrete below or above it. Delamination begins with the corrosion of reinforcement and subsequent cracking of the concrete. A spall is a fragment, which has been detached from a larger concrete mass. Spalling is a continuation of the delamination process whereby the actions of external loads, pressure exerted by the corrosion of reinforcement or by the formation of ice in the delaminated area results in the breaking off. Spalling of patched areas may occur due to continued deterioration of the old concrete and subsequent breaking off of the new patch. Spalling may also occur in areas of localized high compressive load concentrations, such as at structure supports, or at anchorage zones in post- tensioned concrete. Cracks resulting from externally applied loads initially appear as hairline cracks and are harmless. As the reinforcement is further stressed the initial cracks open up and progressively spread into numerous wider cracks. After this point the concrete cracks and the tensile force is transferred completely to the steel reinforcement. Internal restraint forces are caused by the differential expansion or contraction of the exterior surface of concrete relative to the interior mass of the concrete. Cracks resulting from the actions of external restraint forces develop in a similar manner as those due to externally applied loads. Movement cracks may be of any orientation and width, ranging from fine cracks above the reinforcement due to formwork settlement, to wide cracks due to foundation or support settlement. Differential movements or settlements result in the redistribution of external reactions and internal forces in the structure. In Ontario, there exists several sources of aggregates that react adversely with the alkalis in cement to produce a highly expansive gel. The expansion of the gel and aggregates occurs due to hydroxyl ions in the concrete pore solution, which under moist conditions, leads to cracking and deterioration of the concrete. Once the alkali-aggregate reaction starts, there are no remedial measures to stop or reverse the process of deterioration. However, sealing the surface to reduce the moisture infiltration does slow down the reaction. The appearance of concrete affected by the reaction is shown in Figure 2.8.  Surface defects are not necessarily serious in themselves however, they are indicative of a potential weakness in the concrete. Segregation is caused by concrete falling from a height, with the coarse aggregates settling to the bottom and fines on top. Honeycombing is produced due to the improper or incomplete vibration of the concrete. Efflorescence is a deposit of salts, usually white and powdery. Exudation is a liquid or gel-like discharge through pores or cracks in the surface. Severe POP-OUTS are shallow depressions resulting from the breaking away of small portions of the concrete surface. Severe ABRASION is the deterioration of concrete brought about by vehicles or snow-plough blades scraping against concrete surfaces. SLIPPERY CONCRETE SURFACES may result from the polishing of the concrete deck surface by the action of repetitive vehicular traffic. There are no severity descriptions for slippery concrete surfaces as this is a serious and potentially hazardous situation. Flexure Cracks Shear Cracks Torsion Cracks Axial Cracks Figure 2.2.3 STEEL The use of steel has progressed from cast iron, wrought iron, rivet steel and plain carbon s. Corrosion is the deterioration of steel by chemical or electro-chemical reaction resulting from exposure to air, moisture, de- icing salts, industrial fumes and other chemicals and contaminants. Weathering steel, on the other hand, will form a relatively smooth rust layer, called a patina, which protects the underlying metal. Weathering steel must be exposed to intermittent wetting and drying cycles to form a tightly adherent patina. In less than ideal circumstances, the patina may not form or may be penetrated and delaminated, resulting in progressive corrosion. Corrugated Steel Pipe culverts experience rusting after the protective galvanizing coating has worn off. Permanent deformation of steel members can take the form of bending, buckling, twisting or elongation. Permanent deformations may be caused by overloading, vehicular collision, or inadequate or damaged intermediate lateral supports or bracing. Permanent twisting deformations appear as a rotation of the member about its longitudinal axis. Uckling deformations normally occur in a direction perpendicular to the applied load. Buckling may also produce local permanent deformations of webs and flanges of beams. Local buckling of culvert wall usually near areas of higher curvature primarily due to bending forces. Bolt Tilting is the bearing failure at the location of the bolt holes. Global deformations usually occur on the roof or sometimes on the floor of the culvert.  Steel Culverts - Medium - Bolt Tilting, Crimping or cusping 10 mm height. Any deformation 10 of diameter. - Severe - Crimping 10mm height. The location of the deformation within the member, and the location. of the member in the structure should be recorded. Brittle fracture may result at fatigue prone details after initial fatigue cracking. Details in fatigue stress categories E and F are most susceptible to fatigue crack growth. The primary factors leading to fatigue cracking are the number of applied stress cycles. Cracks caused by fatigue usually occur at points of tensile stress concentrations, at welded attachments or at termination points of welds. Welded details are more prone to cracking than bolted or riveted details. Grinding off the weld reinforcement to be smooth or flush with the joined metal surfaces improves fatigue resistance. Cracks can occur due to improper installation or due to higher bending or compressive forces in the culvert walls. Bolted and riveted connections are also susceptible to cracking or tearing resulting from prying action, and by a build-up of corrosion forces between the parts. Cracks that are parallel with the direction of stress are usually not as serious however, those Members perpendicular are very serious. Loose connections can occur in bolted, riveted or clamped connections. Immediate action is required when cracks are noticed i.e. notify bridge owner. Loose connections may not always be detectable by visual or hands-on inspection. Cracking or excessive corrosion of the connector or gusset plates or the fasteners may be indications of loose connections. Tapping the connection with a hammer is one method of determining if the connection is loose. All connecting member plates shall be inspected with the overall connection rating based on the worst of these components. For Bailey Bridges, the Bailey panel connection pin shall be rated as a connection.

Location of loose or missing fasteners, as well as areas of corrosion on gusset plates, should be described.
