Wood was one of the earliest materials used for structures, and is still in common use today. This is largely due to its availability in a variety of structural sizes and ease of handling. The following defects commonly occurring in wood are described - Checks, Splits and Shakes. Weathering is the gradual deterioration of wood due to exposure to the actions of sun, rain, wind, frost and atmospheric pollutants. Treated wood weathers more slowly to a gray-brown colour and may exhibit a rough wash-board appearance. Light weathering is shown in Figure 2.4.1a. Rot or decay is the biological decomposition of wood caused by micro-organisms called fungi. Rot develops in progressive stages, usually through cracks, knots, holes and at the ends of members. The most common method of reducing rot or decay in wood is by pressure treatment with preservatives. Wood appears as a grey fibrous mass. It develops at or above ground contact and may attack both the surface and interior portions of wood. Brown rotted wood has a reddish-brown appearance, and in advanced stages has a checked or crumbly surface. Soft rotted Wood has a soft, spongy surface. The wood sounds hollow when tapped and offers little resistance to penetration by a sharp object. Considerable damage with 10 to 20 section loss Very Severe - The wood can be crumbled and disintegrated

Termites, carpenter ants and wood-boring beetles are the most common insects that attack wood in Ontario. The severity of the insect damage can be judged by the number of holes and tunnels on the surface of the wood. Abrasion is the deterioration of wood brought about by vehicles or snowplough blades scraping against wood surfaces. Wear is usually the result of dynamic andor frictional forces generated by vehicular traffic. It can also result from the friction of ice or water-borne particles against partly or completely submerged members. Cracking, splintering, crushing and shattering are forms of physical damage which result from vehicular collision or from overloading of a member. Particularly susceptible are members already weakened by rot or insect attack. Medium - Surface wear more noticeable with 5 to 10 section loss. Severe - Loss of section between 10 to 20. Shattering is a combined form of crushing and splintering resulting from impact. Fire damage is evidenced by charring and is usually confined to the wood surface. Chemical damage may result from the use of non-preservative chemicals on the wood. The effect of chemicals on the wood is a softening of the surface accompanied by loss of strength. The effect on metal connector plates and fasteners is less critical except in certain circumstances for example, on fasteners with low corrosion resistance. Loose connections may not always be detectable by visual or hands-on inspection. Cracking or excessive corrosion of plates or fasteners, as well as permanent deformation of the connection or members framing into it, may be indications of loose connections. The severity of loose connections depends largely on the number of loose or missing fasteners. The severity of gusset plates depends on the amount of severe or very severe corrosion or cracks. Any unintended gaps that are observed should be measured and recorded. Masonry is made of stones or bricks bonded together by mortar. Although not a common construction material today, masonry was used in Ontario, usually in retaining walls, abutments, piers or arches, primarily in the 19th century. Cracks develop in masonry as a result of non-uniform settlement of the structure, thermal restraint, frost action and overloads. Cracks develop either at the interface between the stone and mortar, following a zig-zag pattern, when the bond between them is weak.  splitting, spalling and disintegration of masonry is caused by the actions of frost, weathering and abrasion or, by theactions of acids, sulphates or chlorides, which cause deterioration in certain types of stones, such as limestone. Figure 2.5.3 shows evidence of loss of mortar in a masonry arch. It should be noted that some structures have been built without the use of mortar. Aluminum is often used in railings, splash guards, drainage systems, signs and sign supports. Aluminum has a strong resistance to corrosion deterioration after the initial formation of aluminum oxide. In less than ideal circumstances this protective layer may fail to form, or be penetrated and broken down to expose the underlying metal. The process of corrosion will then continue with progressive loss of section. Galvanic corrosion may affect the formation of the protective aluminum oxide film or cause the film to flake off. An inert spacer, either nylon or neoprene, should be placed between the two metals to prevent galvanic corrosion. A crack is a linear fracture in the aluminum which may extend partially or completely through the material. Cracks normally develop as a result of fatigue followed by brittle fracture and excessive corrosion. As cracks may be concealed by corrosion by-products, dirt or debris, the suspect surfaces should be cleaned. Loose connections can occur in bolted, riveted or clamped connections. Cracking or excessive corrosion of the connector, gusset plates fasteners, as well as permanent deformation of the connection or members framing into it, may be indications of loose connections. The severity of the connection deficiency shall be based on the condition of the worst component within the connection. In the case of truss members, the connection shall be taken as the entire joint or node location. The location of the loose or missing fasteners, as well as areas of corrosion on gusset plates, should be described. The severity of gusset plates depends on the amount of severe or very severe corrosion or cracks relative to the total plan area. The severity description involves the determination of this ratio. Asphalt pavement is often used as a wearing surface on concrete, steel and wood decks. Wearing Course Is a dense, highly stable, durable, skid-resistant surface course hot mix asphalt. Binder Course is the lower layers of an asphalt pavement. Rigid Pavement Including composite pavements consist of a concrete slab with bituminous overlays. Asphalt defects on concrete decks or slabs are sometimes an indication of deterioration of the concrete surface. Defects in asphalt pavements can be related to the lack of durability of the asphalt resulting from the composition. A crack is a linear fracture extending partially or completely through the pavement. Cracking in pavements may be caused by any one or a combination of the following factors: vehicular wheel loading poor quality material poor compaction placement or quality control. Alligator cracks form a network of multi-sided polygons or blocks resembling the skin of an alligator. Transverse cracks are approximately at right angles to the pavement centreline and may extend partially or completely across the pavement. Edge breaking of the pavement often results from these cracks. The various types of pavement cracks are illustrated in Figures 2.7.1a to 2. 7.1e. Severity Light - 1 mm to 5 mm wide single or multiple cracks - alligator pattern established with corners of polygon blocks fracturing. progressive edge cracking less than 600 mm from pavement edge, either single or two parallel cracks. Medium - 6 Widespread loss of bond and delamination may occur between the asphalt pavement and deck surface, between the waterproofing and the deck surface or between individual lifts of pavement. Loss of bond is not directly visible on the pavement surface however, they may often be detected by hammer sounding or chain drag. Rippling is the result of poor bond of the pavement to the surface below. Potholes are bowl-shaped holes in the pavement caused by the penetration of water through the pavement. Pavements already deteriorated with such defects as alligator cracking and ravelling are prone to the occurrence of potholes. Local delaminations become visible as protrusions or bumps. These are localized upward displacements of the pavement surface. Ravelling is the progressive deterioration and loss of the pavement material from the surface downward. Ravelling can occur anywhere over the surface, but is most common along curb or sidewalk faces. Severe ravelling may occur together with signs of cracking or potholes. Flushing is the migration of asphalt upwards to the pavement surface in pavements with too much asphalt in the mix. It commonly occurs in the wheel tracks, especially during hot weather, by the action of vehicle traffic pressing and squeezing the excess asphalt to the surface. Slippery asphalt surfaces may result from flushing or from the polishing of the coarse surface aggregates. Wheel track rutting is the formation of longitudinal depressions in the pavement at the locations of the wheel tracks of vehicles. There are several types of material defects that commonly occ. ing from 10 mm to 20 mm deep. Coating defects are not necessarily serious in themselves however, they are indicative of a potential weakness in the coating. Coating Related Defects are defects related to the basic chemistry or composition of the coating. Adhesion Related defects are defects which are usually a result of incorrect coating selection, contaminated substrate or improper surface preparation. Application Related Defences are defects that occur when the coating is applied incorrectly. Cracking is an extension of the checking process and usually occurs in a linear pattern and penetrates completely through the coating. Cracking may result from the effects of weathering or continued polymerisation of the coating materials over time. An oxidizing or catalyzed coating applied over a very smooth surface may crack. As the surface hardens and shrinks, very large irregular checks, usually several centimetres across, are formed on the surface in a characteristic alligator pattern. If not over-coated with compatible material then, the mechanism will continue until it completely penetrates to the substrate. Chalking is usually a surface defect and the coating is intact below the chalky surface. Chalking can progress and the thickness of sound coating reduced to the point where the substrate is exposed. Undercutting is also promoted by high moisture vapour permeability of the coating and penetration by oxygen and salts. Intercoat delamination is where one coat separates from another. It is usually related to poor coating application over contaminated surfaces. Peeling is also a result of poor adhesion of the coating either from the substrate or from a previously applied coating. Coating failure is promoted by poor surface preparation, substrate profile and surface contamination. e, such as oil base and alkyd coatings. These oxidize over time to a point where they become porous to moisture, oxygen and chloride ions. Overspay occurs when paint particles fall on the surface outside the normal spray pattern. Dry spray will absorb solvent from the subsequent coats resulting in poor adhesion. Pinholing can be caused by holding the spray gun too close to the surface so that air bubbles are entrained into the coating. pinholing usually occurs in fast drying coatings. SAGS are heavy thicknesses of paint which have slipped and formed curtains on the surface. PINPOINT RUSTING usually occurs when insufficient thickness of coating is applied over a blast cleaned substrate. The profile peaks lack proper protection and continue to rust. Canadian Highway Bridge Design Code, CANCSA S6-00. A stream is defined as a body of water over or under which a structure is built. The defects produced in the stream by the presence of structure components in or near the stream are detailed in this section. An assessment of the stream and channel stability is important for determining the need for protective measures. There are three principal types of streams namely, meandering, straight and braided. A meandering stream is characterized by alternative S-bends which migrate laterally downstream. Meandering streams may be unstable. A straight stream is one where the length of the stream, measured down the centreline of stream, is less than 1.5. A braided stream is identified by numerous General scour is caused by the constriction to the natural flow created by the structure. Local scour occurs as a result of an obstruction to the flow, such as, a pier, an abutment or the toe of the embankment. Ice jamming can cause severe local scour by constricting the opening at the structure. The impact of ice flows can cause bending of exposed steel piles and the breaking of timber piles. PIPING is the subsurface removal of fines by the movement of water through the ground or embankments. Flooding occurs if the opening under the structure was not designed to accommodate the volume of water passing through it. Channel blockage may occur as a result of accumulations of debris due to natural causes, beavers dams, or due to aggradation of the stream bed or banks. Channel constriction produces scour channel profile with increase in flow around the bridge during flood velocity and degradation upstream. Scour around piers is influenced by location of pier to flow. Rip-rap around pier may cause local scour at upstream. Embankments are sloped fills or cuts in the vicinity of the structure. The purpose of the embankments is to provide for a stable change of grade between the roadway and the surrounding ground surface. Embankments are to be considered as primary components if they support the foundation, otherwise, they are tobe considered as secondary components. Faces of embankments may be protected from the effects of erosion or scour by slope protection systems. The purpose of the slope protections is to prevent the erosion or scour of embankments and stream banks in the vicinity of the roadway. Performance defects are also related to the ability of the embankment to provide support to the foundations without appreciable movements. A secondary purpose is to control the growth of grass and vegetation on steep slopes where mechanical equipment cannot be used safely. Material defects in slope protections are related to their ability to protect the embankments and stream banks from erosion or scour. Rip-Rap Stones, Rubble. Random, hand-laid or grouted. Shallow foundations, footings, are used where rock or soil with adequate bearing capacity is at or near the ground surface. Shallow foundations are normally made of mass concrete, reinforced concrete, wood or masonry. Caissons are normally made of large diameter tube piles or box sections made of concrete, steel sheet piles or H piles. Piles or caissons may terminate with or without a footing, which may be located below ground or water level. Abutments are commonly made of mass concrete, reinforced concrete, or wood. Occasionally, masonry, steel piles, precast concrete, wire baskets, and reinforced earth have been used. Piers consist of a number of components, each serving a specific purpose. Retaining walls are commonly made of mass concrete, reinforced concrete, wood. Occasionally, masonry, steel piles, precast concrete, wire baskets, bag mortar and reinforced earth have been used. Bearings are not needed in some structures, for example, culverts and rigid frames. Bearings are made of steel, rubber, neoprene, polymers, aluminum or a combination of these. Bearings are subdivided into two main categories, fixed or expansion bearings, based on their capability for movement. Fixed bearings do not allow for translation but may allow rotation. Expansion bearings allow fortranslation and may also allow rotation, as illustrated in Figure 6.1a to 6.2g. Steel plate bearings may be used with or without translational and rotational capabilities depending on the number of parts provided. Elastomeric bearings provide translation and rotation as a function of their stiffness. Pot and disc bearings provide rotation. Rotation is provided by compression of a confined elastomer or polymer disc. Cylindrical bearings rotate about the axis of the cylinder, while spherical bearings can rotate about any axis. A TFE sheet is often bonded to the lower surface. Rotation for single rollers is provided by the curved surface of the roller. For multiple rollers, rotation isprovided by a pin connection or curved surface in plate above the roller nest.

The performance of the bearing is based upon its ability to support and transfer loads from the superstructure to the supports. Joints consist of the following parts, all of which may not be present at each joint. A gap to allow for movement. Armourings and anchorages on each side of the gap. Seals or sealants in the gap Joints can be divided into open joints which permit the free flow of water and debris, and sealed joints which prevent the flow. Open joints consist of an open gap whose edges may be protected by armouring. Drop-in-T joints have a T section bridging the open gap and supported on the armouring on each side. Finger plate joints have two steel plates cut and arranged to form a series of inter Paved-over-joints consist of any joint that has been paved over with asphalt pavement. To prevent cracking of the asphalt pavement over the joint a groove is sometimes cut or formed in the pavement and filled with a sealant.  Alternating layers of hot poured mastic asphalt and reinforcing mesh are then placed over the joint. Ethylene vinyl acetate joints consist of a precompressed ethylene vinyl seal bonded to the sides of the joint gap. Multiple seal modular joints consist of two or more elastomeric seals placed between three or more steel separation beams which are placed on steel support beams spanning across the joint gap. These joints are used where large movements are required.

The performance of joints as regards movement is based upon the restriction to movement and evidence of insufficient reserve for anticipated further movement. Other parts of the superstructure, such as, decks, curbs, sidewalks, parapet walls, railings and expansion joints are covered in other sections of OSIM. Beams and girders are made of reinforced or prestressed concrete, steel or wood. They may be simply supported, semi-continuous for live and superimposed dead loads, continuous over a number of spans or cantilevered. Beams and girders carry loads by flexural, shear or torsional resistance. Thick slabs are made of reinforced or prestressed concrete or a combination of these. The deck slabs of rigid frames are to be considered as thick slabs.

Thick slabs carry loads by flexural, shear, torsion and axial forces depending on the fixity and configuration of the support systems. Examples of thick slabs used are illustrated in Figure 8.1.2. Half-through trusses are not connected across the top chords allowing for unrestricted overhead clearance. Sway braces or rakers are connected between the top chord and floor beams, or needle beams, to provide lateral restraint. The bottom chords are also connected by lateral bracings below the deck. Lateral bracings and floor systems for the bailey bridges are similar to the half-through trusses described above. Trusses are built up of individual components interconnected in triangular arrangements in such a manner that the components resist applied loads. Some of the truss components may also be subject to flexural, shear or torsional loads. Typical bailey bridge configurations and components are shown in Figures 8.1.3b and c. For a complete coverage of bailey bridges see reference 1. Open spandrel arches are used where the soil is capable of resisting the horizontal thrust of the arch. In steel tied arches there may also be a system of lateral bracing under the deck. In this type of arch, the deck and floor system is supported on columns carried down to the arch ribs. Filled spandrel arches are commonly used for short spans, and is usually fixed ended. The sides of this arch are closed by retaining walls and wingwalls. Barrel arches have sides that are open and therefore there are no retaining walls. steel arches consist of individual rolled sections or are built-up by bolting, riveting or welding several sections together. Concrete arches are usually monolithically cast, with the result that the interaction and stress distribution among the components is extremely complex. When the arches have fixed ends they are very sensitive to differential settlement or rotation of the foundation, which may produce overstressing and cracking. A tunnel is a bridge constructed through existing ground. In most cases it provides access to pedestrian, rail or vehicular traffic. Soil- steel structures are comprised of corrugated steel pipe or plates, and soil. Culverts, tunnels and soil-steel structures are divided into two main types according to cross-section namely, open invert and closed invert. Vertical loads from the overlying soil and traffic are transmitted by arching action to the underlying soil. Where these structures are used to carry water their basic components can be divided into inlet, barrel and outlet. Diaphragms span between the primary load carrying components such as beams, girders, deck trusses or are located inside box sections. Typical examples of culverts, tunnels and soil-steel structures are illustrated in Figure 8.1.5c.  load bearing diaphragms directly support superstructure reactions or are designed for jacking purposes. Non-load bearing diafragms provide lateral support or restraint to other superstructure components. Sway bracings may be solid, or built up from individual steel or wood sections which are assembled together. Lateral bracings are normally made from single components but sometimes may be made into frames. as beams, girders, trusses and arches and are normally located in the horizontal plane.

Wood decks are commonly used on secondary roads and rural highways. Orthotropic steel decks consist of a flat steel top plate surface welded to a supporting system of steel girders. The top surface of the deck is either left exposed and acts as the wearing surface or is protected by an additional wearing surface. A waterproofing membrane placed between the deck and asphalt wearing surface also provides additional protection. The only differentiation between a curb and a sidewalk shall be width. Curbs and sidewalks are located parallel to the side limits of the roadway. Sidewalks and curbs are sometimes built on supports which cantilever beyond the deck limits. These supports shall be inspected as part of the floor system floor beams. Curbs and sidewalks can be constructed of concrete, wood, asphaltic concrete or steel. Precast masonry is sometimes used as well. Typical examples of curb and sidewalk construction are illustrated in Figures 9.1.1 and 9.3. Drainage from the approaches is normally drained into drainage ditches or caught at catch basins before it reaches the structure. Surface drainage on structures is channelled along the curbs and drained through deck drains or allowed to drain off the deck. Deck drains are anchored to the deck by metal bars, or rely on their shape.  Deck drains vary in size and shape, and vary from single pipes to prefabricated pipe and catch basin units. Deck drains can also occur individually or be interconnected to an extensive collection system terminating at storm sewers. In either case, deck drains must extend below or away from structure components below the deck. Decks and wearing surfaces shall be considered as primary components. Drainage ditches, gutters and catch basins in the approaches to the structure are detailed

Top surfaces of exposed decks are directly subject to the adverse effects of weather, traffic and the use of de-icing salts and chemicals. Performance of curbs and sidewalks relates to their ability to provide safe and comfortable passage for pedestrians. Curbs also serve to channel roadway surface drainage to deck drainage systems. Deck drains, drainage ditches, gutters and catch basins shall be considered as auxiliary components. Material defects are as given

The performance of deck drains and drainage systems relates to their ability to remove water from the deck and approaches. Trapped or ponded water is a safety hazard, particularly when frozen. Inadequate discharge of approach drainage results in erosion of the approach fills. Material Condition States are used to categorize the condition of an element based on the severity of material defects. Four Material Condition States have been defined for bridge elements. The condition of bridge elements is defined to be in any one or more of these Condition States. An exceptionally poor localized zone in a critical element may render the entire element ineffective. For such cases, the particular element can be considered to be 100 Poor and immediate action must be taken. This includes notifying the owner to initiate temporary repairs and a strength evaluation. The importance of recording quantities of defects cannot be over-emphasized. Using rough percentages without some sort of verification will usually lead to a grossly inaccurate estimation of rehabilitation needs. For many elements, the condition states will be recorded as an area measurement, m2. For some elements, such as the expansion joint armouring, the data is recorded by linear metre. For example, a bridge with 10 bearings may have 5 bearings in excellent condition, 3 bearings in good condition, 1 bearing in fair condition and 1 Bearing in poor condition. As a general rule of thumb, the following philosophy is used for most condition state tables i Excellent This refers to an element or part of an element that is in new as constructed condition. No visible deterioration type defects are present and remedial action is not required. In concrete, any type of spalling or delamination would be considered poor since these defects usually indicate more serious underlying problems. These types of defects may trigger a preventative maintenance type of remedial action e.g. sealing, coating, etc. For most elements, a general progression through the various condition states occurs over time. The difference between The Excellent and Good condition states is not always obvious from a distance. Minor defects can be detected upon close visual inspection of elements more than 5 years old depending on the exposure environment. The presence of material defects usually triggers further, more detailed investigations. Additional investigations are usually triggered when a pre-determined percentage is exceeded in the poor Condition State. In addition, material defects often lead to performance deficiencies, which would trigger other follow-up actions, such as a strength evaluation. ies and corresponding follow-up

It includes routine maintenance items as well as targeted structural repairs to a specific element. Routine maintenance is an important part of prolonging bridge life. Non-Destructive Testing Methods for Detection of Defects in Steel Components. A comprehensive non-destructive testing program of steel bridge components should be carried out whenever the members are cleaned to bare metal. Non-destructive testing allows materials and structures to be examined for defects without changing or destroying their usefulness. A wide variety of techniques have been devised among which the most commonly used, in addition to visual inspection, are Liquid penetrant or dye penetrant LP Magnetic particle MP Ultrasonic Testing UT Eddy Current testing ET Radiographic RT. The standards permit minor surface discontinuities and non-significant internal defects which are smaller 4-1-1than the minimum allowable size. These defects, which remain in the finished product and are smaller than the maximum allowable defect size, usually have little effect on the strength of the member. Non-destructive techniques can be applied in the field to identify and evaluate defects. Corrosion combined with cyclic stresses causes stress corrosion cracking. This results in the reduction of a components strength and ability to carry design loads. A liquid penetrant, a brilliantly coloured penetrating oil, is applied to the cleaned surface and allowed to seep into the surface defects for thirty minutes or more. Excess penetrant is then removed and a developer agent is sprayed onto the surface. The developer dries to a white chalky coating and remains unchanged in the absence of any defects. The sequence for liquid penetrant application and typical images are shown in figure 1.1. Advantages Highly portable Relatively inexpensive Can be applied to a wide variety of non-porous surfaces Rapid method of inspection Results can be recorded photographically. Magnetic Particle Magnetic Particle Testing is used to detect surface and near surface defects. Fine magnetic particles low retentivity iron powder distributed over the surface are attracted by the leakage field and held magnetically to form an outline of the defect. Both AC and DC electric current is suitable for magnetizing steel components. Surface defects are most readily detected with AC magnetization. DC magnetization provides greater penetration for detection of subsurface defects. Advantages Surfaces must be reasonably smooth to avoid non-relevant indications. Non-conductive coatings must be removed where the prods contact the metal. Prod method of magnetization can cause arc burns and possible cracks. High frequency sound waves are introduced into a material for the detection of surface and internal defects. The reflected waves returning to the source can be displayed as pulses or signals on the screen of a cathode ray tube. The travel time of the returning pulses is a measure of the distance to the interface of the defect. Ultrasonic systems can detect discontinuities that are larger than one half of the wave length of the signal. A system operating at 5MHz will detect defects larger than about 0.5mm.  angle-beam method and contact pulse reflection can detect internal defects and fatigue cracks. Few restrictions on size of work piece Ideal for testing wrought materials and welds. High noise levels are produced by coarse grain structures such as cast iron. Eddy current testing is a method based on the principles of electromagnetic induction. The component or part thereof to be tested is placed within or adjacent to a coil which is excited by an alternating current. As the induced current fluctuates, an eddy current is produced which flows in a closed loop inside the test material. Radiographic Testing is based on the ability of ionizing radiation in the form of X-rays or Gamma Rays to penetrate solid materials to produce an image on film or a fluorescent screen. Skilled and experienced technicians required to interpret the indirect test results. Cracks or defects absorb less of the available radiation and create a darker image than the sound material. Cracks with depths of about 1.0mm or more should be detected under normal conditions. This method is not well suited for testing i The use of ultrasonic testing would be a suitable test method in place of radiographic testing. The technique will confirm a discontinuity on the surface of a component and show its size but with no indication of the depth. Magnetic particle testing is a simple method for quickly evaluating extensive welds and surface areas. It too is most suited to detecting surface discontinuities. Methods for detecting deterioration in wood described herein are separated into two groups namely, those which identify exterior or surface deterioration, and those which are used to assess deterioration in the body of the wood. There is no single tool or method that can accurately determine the extent and severity of deterioration. Of the methods discussed, none can satisfactorily identify all defects. Probing with a knife, awl or screw driver can locate decay near the surface of the wood. Decay is indicated by excessive softness and lack of resistance to penetration. Sound wood has a fibrous structure and pries out as long splinters, while decayed wood breaks abruptly and crumbles into small pieces. A pilodyn figure 2.2.3 is a spring-loaded pin device that drives a hardened steel pin into the wood. The depth of pin penetration is used as a measure of the degree of decay. The existence and extent of the problem should be confirmed and defined with core samples. Sounding is a commonly used method and involves striking the surface of the component with a hammer. A dull or hollow sound may indicate the presence of internal voids due to decay. Moisture meter measures the electrical resistance of the wood between two metal pins. The resistance measured is then correlated to the moisture content in the wood. Moisture contents in excess of about 30 indicate conditions suitable for decay. A small hole is drilled into the wood figure 2.3.3b and a probe is inserted into the hole. The probe measures zones or regions of decreased resistance. If the readings drop 50 to 75 to that of sound wood, the region is drilled and cored. A hand drill with a 10mm to 20mm diameter bit is used to drill a hole into the wood. Zones or pockets of decay and deterioration are noted by ease of drilling and by examination of wood shavings. Drilling and coring are generally used to confirm suspect areas of decay identified by other methods sounding, moisture meter etc. The presence of fungi is indicative of wood in an early stage of decay and in need of treatment. Dull tools will break, crush and splinter the wood making interpretation of samples and results difficult. The piece of pressure treated wood is used as a plug to repair damage done by boring. A shell-depth indicator is a metal bar or rod which is notched or hooked at one end and inscribed with ruled markings. The inspector can thus determine the depth and extent of decay and remaining solid portions as read from the ruler markings. Sonic wave velocity, acoustic emission and stress wave analysis have been used for examining wood. These methods involve the use of devices which emit and pick up sound waves as they travel over the surface and through the depth of the wood. High frequency sound waves are induced into the wood by means of a transducer and picked up by another mounted on the opposite side. Advantages Can determine the approximate location and area of deterioration. Can be used to evaluate the saturated zone at the water line. Disadvantages Still developmental to some extent. 4-2-162.4 Post-Inspection Procedure and Treatment Several of the inspection methods and tools described involve the removal or destruction of a portion of the wood. These locations, such as at drill and probe holes, will become entry holes for insects and decay. All the surfaces at these locations must be thoroughly treated with an approved preservative. A significant number of Ontario bridges are built over waterways with abutment or pier foundations either partly or totally submerged. These components cannot be thoroughly evaluated from the water surface and must be occasionally inspected below to determine their condition and state of deterioration. Conditions beneath the surface of the water are relatively constant throughout the year. Material which is continuously submerged remains saturated and there is little oxygen available to promote deterioration. The pH of most surface water is close to neutral and temperatures below the surface vary over a narrow range. The underwater environment is hostile. It is cold, particularly when one is submerged for an extended period of time. A wide variety of methods have been developed for underwater inspection. Several of these techniques are described ranging from low water wading, skin diving, and diving with SCUBA or a surface supported air supply. The use of divers using SCUBA or a surface supply is regulated by the Department of Labour. All structural components are visually inspected, where visibility permits, or examined tactually. Observed conditions are recorded through notes and taped recordings of voice communications between the diver and the surface. T approved personal floatation device.

Diving work performed by a diver, whether with SCUBA or a surface air supply, is governed by the Diving Regulations under the Occupational Health and Safety Act. Visibility beneath the water surface is often restricted and the entire bridge component may not be visible. A meaningful assessment will depend upon t. .3 of this manual. The underwater 5-1-2 inspector should be knowledgeable in bridge design and construction details. All underwater investigations should be carried out under the direct supervision of a Professional Engineer. All members of the diving team must be fully trained in the use of all diving equipment and devices and in the performance of underwater work.  Ultrasonic testing of concrete under ideal conditions is difficult to successfully carry out. This is due to the unique cracking patterns that develop in the material and block the sound waves. The problems encountered are compounded underwater and although it can be used, the results are not always reliable. Magnetic particle testing techniques are also used underwater for cracks or discontinuities in the surface of components. The process is the same as used on the surface except the magnetic particles are in a water suspension of fluorescent dye. Care and experience are required to assess the results obtained. Such an inspection of the entire structure can be carried out relatively quickly in the presence of minimum deficiencies. Concrete structures will experience little in the way of deterioration below the critical zone at the water line. With all structures in the fresh water of Ontario, deterioration of underwater components is generally going to occur at and just below the water surface and at the interface with the soil. The most severe deterioration of all materials will be in the wave zone where they are exposed to the deleterious affects of both the water and the atmospheric environment Underwater inspections are usually carried out using simple, non-destructive testing techniques. The level of detail required will dictate the procedures and equipment to be used. A Level 1 Inspection will provide a v A tactile examination of the exposed underwater surfaces of a structure in sufficient detail to detect major damage or deterioration. It will provide a general assessment of the condition of the submerged components. At the surface, abrasion resulting from floating ice and debris will usually provide a clean surface for observations. Where there is active erosion, characteristic depressions will be observed at the upstream face of the bridge piers and abutments. Significant structural defects are to be measured and photographed in sufficient detail to facilitate a preliminary structural assessment. A Level 2 Inspection is a highly detailed inspection of critical structural elements. It will usually entail extensive cleaning of the structural elements to remove all algae and bio-fouling. Sampling of materials for analysis and testing may also be required. The detailed inspection of steel structures will be directed primarily toward the joints and fasteners. Cleaning of the components will be carried out with a wire brush or a water-jet to expose bare metal for a careful and thorough visual examination. Where defects are identified or suspected the area

Mechanical fasteners will be examined for corrosion and tested for tightness. Flanges of H piles can be measured using an outside calliper, vernier calliper or a micrometer. Discreet pits in the surface of the component should be measured for depth using a pit gauge. Deterioration of concrete due to exposure in fresh water is normally insignificant. The joint pattern in masonry structures materially limits the use of non-destructive testing procedures. A qualitative assessment of the mortar joints can be made using a chisel or screw driver. To quantify any observations requires core drilling vertically downward because of the extreme care required to recover even the best mortar in the joints.

A scour critical bridge is one with abutment or pier foundations which are unstable due to scouring. This assessment will be based on a geotechnical evaluation of the site. Based on soil types and the water velocity through the bridge opening the following scour potential ratings should be applied. A rating of 6 indicates scour will never be a significant problem whereas a rating of 3 or less indicates the need for further investigations and possible protective measures. Each structure must be rated based on the potential for collapse. Stream bed must be carefully evaluated by probing or through various geotechnical techniques. A visual examination of the stream bed by a diver will indicate if active erosion is occurring and will identify exposed piles or the underside of spread footings. Stream bed, both upstream and downstream of the structure and within the water passages should be sounded where any potential exists for scour. Sounding is best obtained by using a recording type echo sounder with particular attention being given immediately adjacent to the abutments and piers. Sonar equipment is reasonably portable and can generally be mounted in or on any type of boat. Weed growth on the bottom will affect the accuracy of observations. Ground penetrating radar is a relatively new procedure for geotechnical investigations. It is well suited to sub-bottom profiling from a boat, or from surface ice. Its greatest advantage over sonar is that the signal is not affected by entrained air. NCHRP Research Report 1114 presents strategies for using uncrewed aerial systems UAS for collecting element-level data during bridge inspections. The recommendations were developed based on extensive review. The research findings will be used by bridge inspection professionals at state departments of transportation DOTs. Interest in and use of UAS has increased in the past 10 years. UAS can collect data underneath or along the fascia without the need to close traffic lanes. Research has not yet focused on the ability of UAS technologies to support the col- lection of element-for Bridge Element Inspection MBEI methodology and format. Guidelines needed to be provided for state DOTs to select the appropriate UAS Technologies for element-level bridge inspection. NCHRP Project 12-122 sought to develop guidelines for state departments of transportation and other bridge owners regarding using uncrewed aircraft systems UAS to collect element-level inspection data. The objectives of this project were to 1 develop a selection process for UAS technologies, 2 develop operator and team qualifications, 3 develop a This final technical report includes a literature review, a review of multiple bridge inspections conducted with two UAS form factors, and a discussion of the major findings and conclusions. The guidelines will provide organizational structure examples for a UAS program, airframe selection considerations, personnel training, bridge inspection method- ologies, data processing, and data storage. UAS can improve the quality, safety, and efficiency of a Routine Inspection with element-level data collection. UAS did not improve the efficiency of Routine Inspections that would typi- cally be conducted from the ground. Data was reviewed and cataloged in the field during the UAS inspection process. UAS imagery and videos were shared with three qualified bridge inspectors for an in-office desktop review. The reviewers noted that there were observed defects that warranted a closer inspection. The use of uncrewed aircraft systems UAS for bridge inspections has increased dramatically in recent years as advances in airframes, sensors, and onboard computing have made UAS more prevalent in the industry. The capabilities of controlled flight and onboard camera systems make UAS an ideal instrument to perform bridge inspections. for Bridge Element Inspection 2019 will provide needed guidance for the standardization of UAS in the bridge inspection industry. The main objective was to develop guidelines for implementing UAS into routine bridge inspections with element-level data collection. The intent was to test the efficacy of UAS as a means of access to achieve results similar to past inspections. The inspector is not required to be within arms length of bridge elements during the code-specified Routine Inspection.
Final report provides an introduction and overview of the research and report.

Uncrewed Aerial Systems Applications for Bridge Inspections Element-Level Bridge Data Collection C H A P T E R 2 Research Approach A literature review was conducted to establish the current state of the art of UAS related to the inspection of civil infrastructure, including bridges. The use of uncrewed aircraft has expanded in recent years as state and federal agencies explore UAS and implement the technology into their operations. The review also included examples of operator training requirements from various bridge owners, as well as examples of UAS used for bridge inspections. Uncrewed aircraft are also commonly referred to as drones. UAS have been used in several applications because they can enable higher quality and faster data collection. State DOTs and federal agencies have used UAS for construction and traffic monitor- ing, land surveying and mapping. State agencies have been hesitant to implement UAS into their bridge inspection programs. Their main concerns are evolving federal regulations, practicality, cost, comparison with traditional methods, data storage, and whether UAS imagery will be allo. Most popular uncrewed aircraft are rotary aircraft with four, six, or eight independently driven rotors. Multi-rotor aircraft are capable of vertical takeoffs and landings and can hover in place. Sensors used for civil infrastructure applications are commonly RGB, thermal, and infrared cameras. The most commonly used off-the-shelf models for bridge inspec- tions have been DJI Phantom, Mavic, Matrice, and Inspire SenseFly. Flight times range from 10 to 30 minutes, but low battery temperatures have been shown to dramatically decrease flight times. In August 2020, the Defense Innovation Unit of the Department of Defense DOD first pub- The Blue UAS list was spurred by data security concerns regarding foreign-made drones being operated around national security assets. State or federal laws or procurement policies may also limit which UAS agencies may use. The Association for Uncrewed Vehicle Systems International is creating a Green cleared U AS list. Aircraft on the Green list will expedite an aircrafts addition to the Blue List, if requested. Losing a GPS signal may eliminate or reduce the airframes ability to hold a certain position and altitude. Object detection and avoidance are useful not only for navigating without GPS signal, but also for maintaining a constant standoff distance from the structure. An appropriate standoff distance also protects the structure and aircraft from inadvertent collisions caused by environmental conditions or remote pilot error. In controlled environments and in practice the standoff can be as little as 1 ft. Cameras can be integrated into the airframe or stand- alone models mounted to a gimbal controlled by either the remote pilot or a sensor operator. Integrated cameras are lighter and smaller than stand-alone cameras but come at a cost of image resolution. Most integrated and stand-alone cameras offer manual in-flight controls to adjust the exposure and account for low-light conditions. There are no minimum requirements for camera resolution, just as there are no vision require- ments for bridge inspectors. SUAS, under 55 lbs in the national airspace are given in 14 CFR Part 107. An exemption can be made to 49 USC 44807 for UAS weighing more than 55 lbs. Anyone operating the UAS must have a remote pilot certificate with an sUAS rating. UAS operations from a moving aircraft or vehicle are generally prohibited. UAS operations are limited to visual line of sight VLOS only. Operations over people are further classified into four categories, with categories 13 based on the size of the aircraft or maximum impact energy. Operations in Category 4 require a 14 CFR Part 21 airworthiness certificate but are allowed out- side a closed-access area. UAS operations at night are also allowed, but the aircraft must have anti-collision lighting visible at 3 statute miles. Remote identification requirements have been updated to take effect in March 2024. Waivers can be obtained for most UAS regulations, but at least the same level of safety must be provided. The FAA promulgates the minimum requirements to legally operate an sUAS. U.S. federal agencies, and cities have established additional policies for using UAS in their operations. These policies generally include flight crew training, planning, and operations. Table 1. UAS training requirements for various local, state, and federal entities. Most agencies require a minimum number of training flights or hours before UAS can be operated on. The U.S. Forest Service 32-hour agency training course 3 takeoffslandings within 90 days 2020 summarizes training requirements for agencies. Most agencies require a minimum number of flights or hours over a period of 13 months before a remote pilot may operate UAS on a project. Ongoing research is looking to establish standardized tests for evaluating claims from UAS manu- facturers and remote pilot competency for bridge inspections. The UAS test will likely be a structure selected by a DOT for evaluating their remote pilots and UAS. Typical defects will be provided in the obstacle course which the user must identify and quantify. It is unclear if this will be done in real time or in post-processing. All bridge types can be inspected with uncrewed aircraft, although how well the aircraft can access certain bridge elements varies. In many cases, it was established that the exterior of the superstructure fascia girders, top of bridge decks, truss members could be easily inspected with UAS. UAS have also been flown in manual mode around the exterior of individual elements, using GPS and proximity sensors. Inspecting the underside of bridge decks or the interior of girders and trusses has proven to be more challenging. Most issues stem from the loss of GPS signals, low clearance underneath the bridge or between members, inadequate viewing angle, and magnetic interference from steel structures. Interior of truss structures are areas where published UAS inspections are deficient. Clearance between members can prevent larger airframes from accessing certain areas, requiring a smaller aircraft or preventing UAS from being used altogether. Concrete spalls, exposed rebar, efflorescencestaining, and cracking are all readily apparent in still images and recorded videos. The imagery must be normal to the surface to accurately estimate the size of the defect. Inspection-specific UAS can even carry both RGB and thermal infrared cameras. Clear identification of fatigue cracks is also a persistent issue in UAS bridge inspections. Vibration, low illumination, camera angle, accessibility, and obstructions dirt, corrosion, previous mark- ings all combine to make fatigue crack detection with UAS difficult. Known fatigue cracks have been observed with standoff distances from 5 to 25 ft, depending on the system. Similar-looking defects have also been misidentified as fatigue cracks. Distortion of steel elements can be observed but may go unnoticed if a UAS cannot view an element from the appropriate angle. The largest benefit of using UAS to supplement routine bridge inspections is access to areas that would have previously required a ladder, UBIT, or aerial lift. These elements include steel bridge decks, interiors of pin and hanger connections, cables and anchorages, and towers above the height of the roadway. Smaller, low-clearance, and low-risk bridges that can be accessed without specialized equipment may not benefit from UAS inspections. UAS-assisted inspections for such structures may increase inspection costs, but higher-quality imagery could still be acquired. 22 survey responses were received. Of the responses received, 95 21 of 22 respondents had received some bridge inspection train- ing. More than half 55, or 12 had more than 10 years of experience. 18 4 of 22 of respondents thought the inspector should be within 10 ft. of an element to conduct a Routine Inspection. 82 18 of 22 thought the Inspector should be close enough to visually assess the condition state. 40 8 of 20 of the respondents were somewhat or extremely comfortable. Some common uses for UAS in bridge inspections were to take photos and videos, supplement Routine Inspections, replace or support inspections with UBITs, monitor and document deficiencies, assess the need for in-depth inspections, and provide an enhanced visual inspection of non-critical elements. Around the world, UAS are used for bridge inspection for many of the same reasons that U.S.- based researchers and DOTs have identified. Countries using UAS for other infrastructure inspections include Australia, France, the Netherlands, Singapore, Sweden, and the United Kingdom. Only the United Kingdom and New Zealand include an allowance for UAS as an alternative access method in their respective bridge inspection manuals. Both prohibit UAS from certain applications. UAS cannot be used if the inspector is required to be less than 3 meters from the structure. Union Pacific has used UAS extensively for structural inspections throughout their network. UAS use is also widespread among international railroads. Within these organizations, use cases for UAS included bridge, culvert, and track inspections. Imagery and video data collected during a UAS-assisted inspection can be used in multiple forms, with varying degrees of post-processing. Complex deliverables such as point clouds, 3-D models, and orthomosaics can be generated from UAS imagery but require more precise data collection tech- niques. UAS imagery can be easily incorporated into an inspection report. Little research has been done to establish whether element-level inspection data collected using UAS is consistent. There is a need for multiple inspectors to work independently to review the same UAS imagery. Inspectors using only UAS imagery were less accurate than those conducting a hands-on inspec- tion. Prior experience with UAS inspections increased accuracy. Post-processing tools can allow lengths and areas to be directly calculated from the imagery. Some areas of bridges or bridge elements were challenging to inspect with UAS. These areas and elements included the interior of girders top of the bottom flange and interior cross frames. These knowledge gaps were used to inform the selection of bridges to be inspected. The literature review identified aspects of UAS inspections that warranted additional research. Aspects of particular interest included cost and time comparisons, optics and proximity comparisons, and a brief study of AI to assist inspectors. 42 of the 100 bridge elements given in the 2014 element-level coding chart were inspected using the two UAS form factors. The two UAS form factors both had certain limitations that would affect how they would be used in a routine bridge inspection. The major differences were the size and stability of the airframe and the characteristics of the sensor. Both airframes and UAS for bridge inspections in general could be conside in general. The FF1 airframe could be launched and landed by hand, which was beneficial at bridge sites with steep embankments. The advanced obstacle avoidance made constant adjustments to keep the air- frame stable around exterior and interior bridge elements. There was enough space to fly the UAS at a farther distance. The UAS was more stable when flying between prestressed I-girders and steel and prestressed concrete box girders because of the larger planar surfaces and the visual sensors it uses for stabilization. However, when the remote pilot was inspecting interior elements, these adjustments were more discomforting due to the enclosed space and the perceived instability of the airframe. Company 2 performed an AI analysis using only the 2-D images from Bridge 3 approach spans but acknowledged that their algorithm was trained to identify cracks only in asphalt pavements. Company 2 noted that their models can be trained for specific applications and materials.  AI-based inspection technology is still relatively young, and only recently has there been focused effort to apply the technology to bridge inspections with element-level data collection. Most research has focused on detect- ing cracks and other deficiencies in concrete and asphalt materials in which defects are readily detectable. UAS can be incorporated into rou- tine bridge inspections with element-level data collection. Commercially available services also provide non-AI benefits, including georeferenced images, 3-D models, point clouds, measurement tools. The FF1 UAS was compact, portable, and had advanced obstacle avoidance capabilities. The small size meant the airframe was more susceptible to wind gusts and vortex shedding as around cables. The lower-resolution camera was adequate when flown close to the bridge elements. The FF2 UAS had dual operator controls, which meant the workflow could be effi- ciently split between a remote pilot and a sensor operator. The higher-resolution interchangeable prime and zoom lenses were also capable of collecting higher-quality video and imagery. The usefulness of a UAS depends on the structure type and current inspection methods. A Routine Inspection of a common steel or concrete multi-girder structure is typically conducted by telescopic-aided binoculars visual observation from the ground below and by walking the bridge deck. UAS may provide enhanced access, better viewing angles, and more thorough imagery. Using a UAS in this manner may reduce or eliminate the need to mobilize heavy equipment, set up traffic control, or work in traffic. UAS would also provide time savings if used to inspect non- fracture-critical elements. A small subset of data was sent to three inspectors who were not present on site. This work was done by a team member who was present when the video was collected. One reviewer noted a bent cross frame and a poor-quality weld that warranted closer inspection.  AI applications hold promise for bridge inspections, but bridge owners need to treat the technology as another tool to assist inspectors. Most AI models and research currently focus on crack and spall detection in concrete elements, with only limited research on crack detec- tion in steel materials. Each State is required to report bridge elements level data to the Secretary of FHWA. As the use of element level inspection techniques has proliferated, the need for updates and enhancements to the standard element specification has been identified. This manual is not intended to supersede proper bridge and element inspection training or the exercise of engineering judgment. The changes made to this document are shown in BOLD RED fonts. The STRIKETHROUGH TEXT indicates any deletions. provides a comprehensive set of bridge elements that is designed to be flexible in nature to satisfy the needs of all agencies. The complete set of elements capture the components necessary for an agency to manage all aspects of the bridge inventory utilizing the full capability of a BMS. The National Bridge Elements represent the primary structural components of bridges. The standard condition states are comprised of good, fair, poor, and severe general descriptions. Units of measure are LENGTH in feet, AREA in square feet, and EACH for enumerated elements. Bridge Management Elements include components of bridges such as joints, wearing surfaces, and protective coating systems. These elements are not intended to be utilized for the purposes of national policy making. NJDOT has developed additional BMEs as necessary. The elements presented within provide the flexibility for an agency to define custom elements in accordance with the defined element framework. The identification numbers 800 and above are used in this manual for any ADEs. The NBE elements are intended to form an element basis for bridge condition assessment in the National Bridge Inventory NBI. An agency is permitted to create NBE sub-elements providing that the sub-Elements can be aggregated back together for NBI submission. The Bridge Management Elements BMEs represent many components of the bridges that require preservation but are not primary structural members. These elements include joints, wearing surfaces, protective coatings, and deck protection systems. The number range of 800 and above has been reserved. Agency may wish to individually define the wearing surfaces typically used in their bridge inventory. In this example, these detailed wearing surface elements would be sub-elements of the general BME for wearing surfaces. The BME would not need to be rolled up aggregated for national reporting. Protective systems may need to be set-up to influence the deterioration rates of certain elements. All of these protective coatings will influence the rate of deterioration of the base element that they are designed to protect. Bridge Management Systems BMS will slow or eliminate deterioration as long as the protective element is in good condition. 4.3 Independent Agency Defined Elements Agencies may identify a business need to develop a completely independent custom element that is not a subset or derivative of an NBE or BME. Such custom elements provide the most flexibility as these elements are not intended to be reported at a national level. Independent agency developed elements could include approach guardrails, slope paving, seismic retrofit components, or tunnels just to name a few. Custom element definitions provide a ready-made framework for capturing items such as tunnels, walls, median barriers, and h. nly limited by the number of required condition states. Bridge inspection based on this manual consists of defining the elements pieces of the bridge and total quantities that exist at each bridge. The condition assessment is complete when the appropriate portion of the total quantity is stratified over the defined condition states. Element defects are typically to be used when the elements condition reaches state 2 or lower. They essentially act to break down the overall element condition into one or more specific observed problems. The specific listing of all defects is optional however the element condition must be inclusive of all defined defects. This manual attempts to cover the vast majority of all bridge elements found on highway bridges in the United States. An inspector may find materials or elements that are not defined during the course of their inspection. The granularity of the defect details is typically not specified with defect descriptive language. Elements with a portion or all of the quantity in state 4 may often have load capacity implications warranting a structural review. Agencies may establish additional guidance to aid the inspector in determining the field circumstances where structural review is warranted.
Each element is displayed within the NBE, BME or ADE

Placing a new noise wall on an existing bridge adds a significant amount of stress on a structure caused by the additional weight and rotational loading. This may result in the need to add additional girders, beams, and diaphragms strengthen the existing bridge deck. The ability to design the noise wall as an integral part of the overall structure addresses most if not all of the issues. Additional costs are still incurred compared to the same bridge without a noise barrier. The proximity of the noise wall to the traveled portion of the bridge usually makes the wall considerably more susceptible to damage compared to most ground-mounted noise walls. Such damage may be caused by vehicle impact, airborne debris such as stones, vehicle parts, snow removal operations, or material from salt spreaders. Bridge-mounted noise walls have raised concerns related to issues such as vehicular sight distance, barrier shading which increases potential for highway icing, and adverse effects on highway lighting. These concerns, except for bridge inspection, are common to both ground-mounted and structure-mounted systems. Noise wall panels or other components are then secured to the beam or posts to create the in- place barrier. Obtaining a smooth or desi. of techniques have been successfully employed to attach noise walls to bridges. Red top of barrier profile with such a system may require each panel to be custom made if the top of parapet profile is not smooth and consistent. Any bottom of barrier jaggedness or gapping can be concealed by flashing. Inserted into parapet This method should only be considered for new bridges. Mechanical anchoring system consists of a wedge shaped nut which is inserted into a drilled or cast hole in the concrete parapet wall. Chemical anchoring systems consist of a two-part epoxy mixture adhesive inserted into the hole. The bolt through system uses long bolts which are inserted into holes either cast or drilled completely through the parapet walls. Cast-in-place bolts - Although a less commonly used method, this anchoring system is considered to be the most effective and least destructive of all methods. Bridge slab may be extended beyond the outside edge of the parapet to provide additional dead load support. Additional barrier anchorage may be provided via angle iron mounted to top of parapet. Post-less systems use either concealed posts or no posts with the panels, typically mounted in the following manners. Masonry Block Noise Barriers are laid up in a manner similar to ground-mounted masonry block barriers. Anchoring is via reinforcing bars extending out of the top of the parapet wall. This type of structure-mounted noise barrier wall is more suitable where short height barriers can provide the desired noise attenuation. A parallel supporting beam or similar structure may be built immediately adjacent to the existing structure. This mounting system is particularly suitable for older or weakened bridges. Fatigue failure of a support structure basically occurs because the stress ranges resulting from the wind or truck-induced gusts exceed the fatigue thresholds at critical details. Most sign support structures are fabricated from structural steel tubes, angles, and plate. The primary loads applied to bridge mounted sign structures are due to natural winds as well as truck gusts. Natural wind gusts exert a fluctuating force that is primarily horizontal, and the resulting motion of the mast arm is also primarily horizontal. The passage of trucks beneath support structures induces both horizontal and vertical gust loads on the structure. Pile supported Retractable Rubber Gravity Hydraulicpneumatic Floating systems. In most cases, quantities of elements are estimated based on the number of elements multiplied by the length or width of the bridge. For example, if there are 10 floor beams on a structure and the bridge is 40 feet wide, you can estimate the total quantity as 10 x 40 400. The quantity for box girder depends on the number of boxes which make up the girder. Integral Deck Girders include both an element for girder as well as one for deck. Timber Abutments typically will get 3 different elements, a timber cap, timber column, and timber abutment. Pile Bent Pier will have two elements, a cap and columns. Any diagonal bracing will not be considered in rating the condition of the columns. Concrete Channels are precast channels with normal reinforcement not prestressed. Record these elements as a reinforced concrete girder. Bridge Management created 05022014, Rev. 1 01312015F2.9 Conventions for Quantities. Quantity for Culverts is the length of the barrel measured headwall to headwall times the number of barrels. Girders are the main longitudinal superstructure members.  Quantity for Arch is measured along the span length from spring line to spring line in one foot increments. Quantity for Truss is measured in linear feet along the truss a horizontal projection of the measurement. Use pier wall element anytime the pier supporting member is 10 feet or greater in width. Indian Roads Congress iiIRCSP40-2019 GUIDELINES ON REPAIR, STRENGTHENING REHABILITATION of CONCRETE BRIDGES.  IRC first brought out IRCSP40 Guidelines for Techniques for Strengthening and Rehabilitation of Bridges in the year 1990. Since then lot of advancement have taken place in testing methodology, testing equipment, repair and strengthening techniques and materials. Initial draft was prepared by the Sub-group of B-8 Committee under Chairmanship of Shri P.Y. Manjure. Condition Assessment Criteria has been introduced in this revision. All the results of visual inspection and detailed investigations are to be categorized into five condition states namely Excellent, Good, Fair, Poor and Critical. Bridges, Specifications and Standard Committee approved this document in its meetings held at IRC headquarters on 24th October, 2018. Executive Committee approved the document on 27th October,. 2018 for placing it before the IRC Council. Thereafter guidelines were approved by the IRC council in its 216th meeting held during 79th Annual Session at Nagpur on 22nd November, 2018 for 1IRCSP The deterioration of bridges is a world-wide phenomenon. The consequences faced are premature bridge deterioration, loss of traffic safety or reduction of structural strength. These could be avoided if focused attention is given to conservation of existing bridges through regular monitoring and timely repairs. 2IRCSP40-2019 defines the process and approach for assessment of distresses, diagnosis of causes, proposing remedial measures and the corresponding methods and techniques for the engineering operations. Many terms resemble one- another but are not identical. Degradation usually associated with wear and tear with age, also used to denote reduction in quality or strength. Demolition The process of dismantling and removal of existing structure. Disintegration Severe deterioration resulting in breakup of components.  maintenance is usually done periodically. It comprises any activity and work including inspection necessary to enable a structure to continue to fulfill the intended function. May partly or wholly restore a specific component back to the original condition. Repair work is intended to prevent further damages to the members and restore functional performance. Remodeling Includes changes in function and performance of the structure due to change in usage or occupancy. In steel bridges, it could be corrosion, breaking or rupturing etc. These activities would be similar to maintenance activities but on a larger scale. In short, repair activities shall consist of remedial action which would broadly include concrete restoration. Retrofitting is improvement intended to restore a specific structural function or enhancement of bridge status to a higher performance level. Strengthening Increasing the strength of the structure by various means such as plate bonding, jacketing, Carbon Fiber Reinforced Plastic CFRP bonding. Bridges are vital link on the highways and road network and are susceptible to deterioration. Assessment and remedial measures are elaborated in this chapter. The objective is to Establish desired levels of maintenance service.  traffic volumes and gross weight of vehicles have been observed to grow continuously. The tendency is to carry as much load as possible on a single vehicle in order to reduce the transportation cost. Authorities many a times, increases the legal axle load limits which needs to be considered. Environmental factors are accountable for the deterioration of bridges. Extreme climatic conditions such as, abnormal variations in wind speed, water flow temperature and vicinity of foul gases, harmful chemicals etc. aggravate the deterioration mechanisms. More complex the structure of bridges, the more difficult it is to strengthen or rehabilitate them. The understanding of type of the bridge structure and its structural configuration is paramount in deciding the type of repair option to be implemented. 2.5 Geographical conditions Many a times these conditions will influence the nature of rehabilitation that needs to be carried out. Treatment to be given to the bridges located in hills and landslide prone areas would differ from the measures adopted for bridges in coastal areas. Some bridges are strategically located such as those at sensitive areas near countrys borders. Safety and serviceability of both the users and the bridge shall be the 6IRCSP40-2019 prime objective. Bridge condition, deterioration rate, future developmental planning considerations, and remaining life of bridge shall influence policy decision. Fund availability and estimated costs of maintenance repairs including for diversion, if any. The general policy must take into account the number of parameters already described in Para 2.2 above. All the activities of bridge maintenance and repairs shall be institutionalized. The bridges may be divided into non-structural elements with relatively short-life spans.  division between short-life and long-life bridge elements is necessary because of the stronger economic motivation to rehabilitate and strengthen long life elements than short life elements. A consideration of alternate materials and techniques available, their suitability and economy are very crucial while making a decision. Traffic considerations and a division between bridges on type of roads i The best strategies can only be determined in the light of assessment of the present condition of the bridge. The root causes of the deterioration should be evaluated and eliminated. Repair and strengthening operations should be mechanically and chemically compatible with the properties of the original or surrounding material. A routine or principal inspection provides a detailed description of some of the damages where an assessment of the structure may become necessary. Testing techniques and equipment should be capable to determine the extent and type of deterioration or damage. To the extent possible, non-destructive tests should be used. The purpose of evaluation of a distressed structure is not only to determine the effect of damage on the structures life expectancy and carrying capacity, but also, and perhaps more importantly, to the possible extent, its cause. Data resulting from the investigation of a damaged structure including monitoring of its distress form the basis for the decision as to what corrective action must be undertaken. The initial concern should be to find out whether or not there is a risk of failure to the damaged structure. If this risk is present, the first course of action must be to immediately provide an adequate auxiliary support mechanism and to reduce the loads to remove the risk. The urgency of repairs, strengthening or replacement must be evaluated in a technical sense along with realistic cost estimates so that proper priorities can be established in budget planning. The question of urgency must also consider an estimation of remaining life expectancy. The most important step in the design of repairs for rehabilitation andor strengthening work is a careful assessment of the existing structure. Guidelines for this evaluation have been issued separately IRCSP37. ary to evaluate the lord carrying capacity of the bridge. The complexity and magnitude of the repair work will depend on whether - Only the cause of damage has to be rectified or - The structure must be restored to original condition. The designer of the rehabilitation strengthening measures has, therefore, to be very judicious in his approach. When the structural system is complex for accurate analysis, specification more conservative than IRC specification may have to be adopted. The rehabilitation andor strengthening of major bridges is a complex task requiring many a time input from several specialists. The bridge engineer, therefore, has to consult the experts in different fields to work out the appropriate repair plan. Assessment is a complex interaction between structural condition from visual inspection and construction records. Such data can be gathered from investigation of the causes of distress and mechanism of deterioration. Proper preparation and planning are basic requirements to be met in order to carry out professional assessment of distressed bridge. An overview shall be established with typical reasons of deterioration or structural conditions. It shall also include program for various tests. Tests to establish concrete and steel properties considering mechanical and durability aspects shall be carried out. Rate and quantum of corrosion shall be established. Analysis of Cause of Distress Information collected during inspection and investigation data of the bridge structure shall be analyzed. An appropriate protection against the defect cause has to be provided to avoid repetition. An initial concern shall be whether there is any risk of failure of the damaged structure. When there is minor damage, it shall be assessed whether it would aggravate due to service loads. Cost of measures evaluated for rehabilitation, cost of it shall be estimated and incorporated in the budgeting. In case of time dependent damage, estimation of life expectancy is important. Sometimes specification more conservative than the IRC may have to be adopted. The scheme of maintenance, repair and rehabilitation of a bridge would depend upon the following factors.
