Cracks could be of Structural andor Non-Structural in nature. The significance of cracks depends on type of the crack, length, width depth, location, nature orientation, type of structure and whether the width and length increase with time and load. Shrinkage cracks occur within first few hours after initial set due to excessive bleeding and rapid early drying. Drying shrinkage cracks take a few weeks to years for development due to loss of moisture. Thermal contraction cracks could result into exposure of reinforcement, seepage and leaking. Alkali aggregate reaction can be a cause of cracks. Corrosion induced cracks are located directly above or below the reinforcement and occur parallel to rebars. Cracks due to sulphate attack may take several years to develop mostly near or below ground level. Physical salt weathering requires many months to many years for development of cracks in the inter tidal and splash zone. Cracks caused by chemical reaction, alkali silica reaction can lead to serious damages to the concrete and loss of strength and capacity. Delamination is separations along a plane parallel to the surface of the concrete. Spall is a depression caused by separation and removal. Major causes of spalling are corrosion of the reinforcement, overstresses, etc. of surface concrete. Leaching is the accumulation of salt and lime deposits white in colour on the concrete surface. Scaling is the manifestation of loss of concrete in patches. Internal voids may not be detected by hammer rap survey. If tapping produces metallic sound then the concrete is sound and well compacted. Twisting of substructure or superstructure units may be evidence of a settlement of foundation problem. Horizontal cracks near the ends of pre-stressed members may indicate a deficiency of reinforcing steel. Vertical crack in the bottom of the unit and at the support may be a result of restricted movement in bearings. Transverse cracks on top of deck in cantilever bridges associated wit. her causes. Leaching is also evidenced in pre-stressed bridges. Particular attention needs to be paid to the concrete or mortar adjacent to joints. Abnormal deflections could also occur due to loss of pre-stress with time. The composition of the external surface layers is comparatively different from the interior of the structural element. There is a difference in how protection is achieved from impregnation systems and sealers and or coating systems. The efficiency of an impregnation basically depends on the preparation of the surface. The absorption is accomplished via the capillary voids of the concrete. The application may be accomplished by means of a brush, lambskin roller or by spraying. Impregnation protection systems are only suitable where the concrete surface will not be removed by abrasion, damaged or locally affected by the formation of cracks. While impregnation with resins may be successfully used on horizontal surfaces, hydrophobizing impregnations are not suitable for horizontal surfaces. C Coatings is a treatment to produce a continuous protective layer on the surface of the concrete. The materials for coatings to be used shall be organic inorganic polymers such as Acrylics, Epoxy, PU, PMMA or Silicone Resins. Piers above the tidal zone and the superstructures are best coated with Anti-Carbonation Acrylic, Elastic-Elastomeric coating. The coating should have anti carbonation and water vapor diffusion property and should be resistant to action of UV radiation. Oating protects exposed faces of the superstructure and the substructure of concrete bridges from the aggressive action of industrially polluted and marinesaline environment. Cover meters are used to detect steel reinforcement bars and estimate concrete cover over rebar and diameter of the steel reinforcement bar in concrete structures. The method works on electro-magnetic principles. An electromagnetic field is generated by the search head of the meter. Cover-meters can measure the cover with an accuracy of 5 mm up to a depth of about 75 mm. It is possible to obtain the location of reinforcing steel bar, determine the depth of concrete cover and estimate the barsize using the cover meters. The technique is the least complicated and least expensive of all the NDT techniques. The purpose of bridge repair is similar to the vascular network in a road. Using a metaphor, the road network which serves for the national socio-economic activities such as logistics, travels and communications, is compared to a vascular network. Road infrastructure is essential for Cambodia economy. Bridges crossing rivers are vital components of the road network. Damages or collapses of bridges can risk the lives of road users as well as create serious influence to the entire country. Although maintenance-free is ideal during the designed lifespan, the period when maintenance is needed is very long. Health of structure is reduced by age, but the lifespan is 1-1extendable by appropriate maintenance. Maintenance gives a significant effect on the structures performance level and lifespan. If the current condition and the progress of deterioration can be monitored and identified in the early stage, the recovery can be made with minor repairing. If the deterioration is neglected until reaching to the minimum standard, major repair work is needed for the whole recovery. In order to reduce the burden of future maintenance to minimize the life cycle cost consequently, constant and timely inspection and repair work Bridge component consists of deck slab, superstructure, bearing and substructure pier, abutment and foundation. They all should be carried out promptly based on maintenance plan to ensure structural performance. Bridge configuration consists of two sections superstructure comprising deckfloor and girderbeam. Type of superstructure is categorized in terms of material and structural feature. I- shaped steel and H-shaped steel are most commonly used for steel bridge and called Plate girder bridge. Concrete deck bridge is applied for relatively short span bridge since dead load becomes heavier due to its span length. It is advantageous to shortening construction period and saving workload at the site because of its structural simplicity and workability. Though this bridge type used to be most economical for center span of up to 400m, recently it is applicable to the span length of more than 800m. Superstructure is the main bridge part comprise deckfloor and girderbeam. Substructure supports superstructure and transmits its load to the ground. Bearings sustain vertical load such as dead load or live load from the superstructure as well as lateral load by wind or earthquake. Lateral bracing resists against wind and seismic force and sway bracing avoids cross-sectional deformation. Drainage pits are set on a certain interval on the bridge surface. Disintegration - the physical deterioration or breaking down of the concrete into small fragments or particles. Groyne or Spurdike a wall built to change the flow of a river and protect the river bank from scour. Headwall a wall at the end of a culvert to hold the soil fill above the culvert pipe. Gabion wire basket filled with stones. Galvanizing a thin layer of zinc on steel to protect it. Pile a long, thin, foundation driven deep into the ground. Panel a flat frame or plate. Parapet a wall or rail along the edge of bridge. Pre-stressed a way of making concrete stronger with pre-stressing steel bars. Retaining Wall a wall to hold back soil. Riprap layer of loose rocks to protect the river bank from scour. Safety Pins the small clips on a bailey bridge, that Scaling stop the panel pins from falling out. Although accident rate of construction work is about 15 in all accidents all injuries and deaths, it is more fatal and more than half of all accidents are caused by construction. Fatal traffic accidents occur more often in repair work than construction work because repair work is likely to be conducted near traffic flow. As a countermeasure of reducing traffic accident, it is effective to put a men-at-work signboar. Accident can be reduced substantially if appropriate safety measures are prepared in advance and arranged during the construction period. It is essential that repair work should be carried out under the condition where worker safety is completely ensured. Supervisor should not be off guard and keep attention even if no accident period continues. Weeds, bushes and trash on the work site sometimes cause workers to stumble or slip, and make scaffoldings unstable. Some trash contains hazardous substances such as glass, cutlery and syringes, and they may be hidden under weeds and bushes. It is important to remove weeds and trash before repair work. All people entering the work site, not only the workers but also the supervisors, must wear the protection helmet. Sandals are not allowed in the site. Rubber protection gloves should be worn in case of using harmful material harmful to skin. Site cleaning should be carried out every day to keep its safe workable condition. Ground around its columns should be leveled or column length should be adjusted so that its floorboards are kept horizontal and stable. Any worker is refrained from smoking in the work site. Work of the day shall be finished and supervisor shall allow workers to dismiss after the confirmation of the contents of next-day work is done. Any waste generated from the work should brought back without leaving in the site. Fine aggregate is the sand mass all of which goes through 10mm wire sieve and whose 85 of weight volume go through 5mm one. Cement is the concrete component with gray colored and powdery state and hardened by hydrate and polymerized effects when mixed with water or liquid material. Cement is roughly classified into three types portland cement, blended cement and special cement. Concrete with proper workability should be chosen by considering the size and shape of cross- section and reinforcement arrangement. Sand texture is a phenomenon where the water washes away the cement component and fine aggregated stand out on the surface. Material discontinuity called cold joint sometimes appear in the boundary section between layers. Cold joint not only becomes the main factor of deterioration on structural strength. Form vibrators may be used to compact thin walls. Standard allowable placement intervals are shown in Table 4.3. oncrete until the overlying layer of concrete is placed. Internal vibrators must not be used for lateral movement, which may cause segregation. As a rule of thumb, vibration time is about 5 to 15 seconds. Pulling out vibrators slowly is very important to make sure that holes are not left in the concrete. The curing method shall generally be wet curing. Seawater shall not be used for the curing water. The construction joint shall be formed at a position of small shear force and perpendicular to the direction of action of compressive forces on the member. Reinforcement shall be assembled firmly using spacers made of concrete or mortar that is equivalent or superior in quality to the body concrete so as not to cause dislocation during concrete placement. Matter including loose rust, mud, oil, paint or others impairs the bond between concrete and reinforcement. When a lap joint is used, the prescribed length shall be lapped and firmly bound by annealed iron wire of 0.9 mm or more in diameter. The courts at New Delhi shall alone have the sole and Bridge Inspection Guidelines include a list of various defects likely to be observed in an element. The guidelines are put under two separate categories as detailed below A. Bridge Element These sets of guidelines will be applicable to different elements of the bridge. Each will be unique to that element. Concrete 2. Steel 3. Elastomer included in bearings C. Culverts B. Ancillaries footpath, trolly refuge, walkway, OHE mast, pipeline. Inspection of the river flow conditions, and river training works is best carried out during the floods or immediately after the end of the monsoon season. River change the course of their flow frequently. Human activity like farming, mining and navigation also has an effect on river flow.  guide bunds are made to channelize the flow of the river through the bridge and prevent a meandering river from outflanking the bridge. The embankment of guide bund is protected against scour by laying launching apron at its toe. Launch of crates of the apron on the river side are normal and should not be considered as a defect. Inspection engineer should be on a look out for erosion of embankment soil either by river flow or from rainwater. Soil erosion need to be addressed urgently before the onset of the net monsoon season. The purpose of this is to identify any signs of extreme meandering of the river which threatens to outflank the bridge. Spurs or groynes are flexible or rigid hydraulic structure built from a riverbank that interrupts water flow and limits the movement of sediment. Spurs can be attracting, deflecting, or repelling. The floor apron consists of in-erodible material like concrete, flat gabion boxes or some other type of paving. An apron can fail by abrasive action of the river or by the river gouging out material locally from the apron.  approach embankments, though not a part of the bridge structure, are important to maintain integrity of the abutment. The construction of and protection provided to an approach bank is more or less similar to that of the embankment of a guide bund. Inspection of the approach embankment should include the following aspects. Inspection of foundations 2.0. Foundations of bridges are classified as Deep foundations and shallowopen foundations. The main difficulty with inspection of bridge foundations is the lack of accessibility of the foundation. On DFCCIL system, the deep foundations comprise of either well foundation or pile foundation. These foundations transfer the loads and forces from the superstructure to such depths where competent strata is obtained. It is neither advisable nor practical to excavate the soil around the foundation solely for the purpose of inspection. Scour of the riverbed is a dynamic phenomenon and it keeps fluctuating with the flood conditions. Unless the scour is measured during the peak floods or during receding floods, it is unlikely to be observable later on. Normally any tilt of the foundation in the cross dir. and verticality. Tilt along the traffic direction may not readily manifest in the track structure. For most inspections, visual observation of the verticality of the foundation is enough. Settlement should be kept under continuous observation, preferably by installing instruments. All shallow foundations on DFCCIL are made using concrete as a structural element. For defects related to concrete in the shallow foundation, please refer to the guideline for inspection of Concrete structures. Marking of HFL and danger level is a standard practice. Settlement in shallow foundation may also manifest by disturbance in the soil strata surface surrounding the foundation. If a protective floor apronpitching has been laid on the bed, there may be signs of separation between the edge of the footing and the apron. Inspection Engineer has to use his technical knowledge and diagnostic skills in case of any sign of distress related to the shallow foundations. erosion of the soil from under the raft. In some cases, like the archBox bridge, there is little to differentiate between substructure and superstructure. On the DFCCIL system, all piers are made in concrete. Pile caps are the point of transition between the be inspected in a pier. Guidelines for inspecting piers and abutments are given below separately. To cross check the verticalitytilt of the pier, slope of the top surface of the wellpile cap and pier cap should be measured using a spirit level. If the tilt is suspected, close inspection of seating of bearings on pedestal may be carried out. Some special cases, bridges in navigable rivers are provided with fenders to protect it against impact of bargesships. For defects in concrete as a material please refer to a separate guideline on the subject. Portions of the pier lying between HFL and LWL should be given greater attention. Wing walls and return walls are also additional elements of an abutment. Presence of soil around the bed block level increases the possibility of damage due to soil and vegetation. Abutments are subject to active earth pressure and tractivebraking forces in the longitudinal direction. Bulging is a local manifestation of the effect of earth pressure on the walls of the abutment. It is a less serious defect than settlement and tilt as it does not point towards global instability. These areas should be thoroughly examined for signs of cracks. During inspection, one should look out for signs of proper functioning of the weep holes. There are brown stain marks on the walls left by the water draining from the weep hole. Growth of vegetation in the cracks and areas around the dirt wall, bed block and wing walls can result in pressure on the concrete. Bearings are amongst the most critical part of a bridge. Malfunctioning of bearings can result in large forces developing in the superstructure andor substructure. Pedestals on which the bearing rests is also treated as a part of the bearing unit. Inadequate edge distance can result in failure of the pedestal. Over loading or low in-situ strength or pre-existing non-structural shrinkage cracks can lead to more severe cracking or spalling. The checklist for inspection of pedestals is given below. All elastomeric bearings on DFCCIL are reinforced type with steel plates embedded within the elastomers. The space around the bearing and pedestal should be free of any obstruction which can prevent free movement and rotation of the bearing. Elastomeric bearings accommodate horizontal movements by shear strain. While some amount of rotation is to be expected, excessive rotation differential compression in elastomers should trigger investigation. The temperature should also be noted down as it has a direct impact on the thermal expansioncontraction. Under the vertical loads, the elastomers compress and also bulge over the free edges. Slight bulging of theElastomers between the embedded steel plates is a sign that the bearing is participating in load transfer. Excessive bulging in some bearing or in some elastomer layer in a bearing reveal abnormality in load sharing. These should be noted down and reported. The bearing should be in full contact with the soffit of the girder above and the top surface of the pedestal below. Any gap in either of the two contact faces is not a healthy sign and needs to be noted down. A neoprene pot bearing has a stainless-steel plate that is attached to the sole plate. Pot bearing and spherical bearing can be divided into three types fixed spherical bearing, guided spherical bearing and free sliding spherical bearing. Guide bars in the expansion pot bearing restrict transverse movement. A fixed bearing version of this configuration does not possess the stainless-steel plate or the PTFE disc. Pot bearing movement can be measured in the same way as for a sliding plate bearing. The movement is one half of the difference between the front and back distances of the top and bottom plates. If the pot bearing allows movement in two directions, the inspection Engineer should measure transverse movement as well. The temperature at which the measurements are taken should also be recorded. Corrosion should be nipped in the bud by early detection and surface protection measures. Any sign of elastomer on the outer surface indicates that the neoprene element is extruded from the pot. Examine pot bearings for proper seating of the various elements with respect to one another. Check to see that the neoprene pad is properly seated within the pot. Also check if all the bolts connecting the bearing with the girder are properly tightened. Look for any build-up of dirt and debris in and around the bearing. The top and bottom parts of the bearing are bolted to each other to facilitate safe transportation and installation. Post installation, the plates locking the two parts together should be removed to permit free movement.  DFCCIL superstructure also carries footpath, trolley refuges, OHE and utility crossings. This guideline covers inspection of different structural forms of the superstructure. Guidelines for inspection of steel as a structural material is covered under a separate guideline. Midspan deflection should be measured on one fixed point at the midspan on either side, and average of the two values reported as the mid span deflection. The amount of deflection for small spans is not large and slight error in measurement may give misleading results. A more useful purpose of recording the midspan deflection is to track it with passage of time and develop a time-deflection chart. Check whether the outlet of the drainpipe is discharging the water at an inappropriate place of the substructure or crossing below. Superstructure is in direct contact with the live loads. This could either be due to over ballasting or some local damage to the retainer. Any abnormal behavior of the superstructure or any latent defect may manifest through unusual deflection and vibration. I girders are an open section whereas the box is a closed section. The box girder is more likely to be pre-stressed as compared to the I girder. Instead of just measuring deflection at mid-span, it is better to measure the camber as it provides more reliable information.  Reference points should be made on either side of the track and separate camber diagrams can be drawn for the up and down face. Anchorage is a point along the pre-stressing cable in post tensioned system where the prestressing system is most vulnerable. Some areas need greater attention as these are known to be points of greater stress and locations where distress is seen more often. Steel plate girders are welded type and all field joints are bolted HSFG bolts. Steel girders being lighter than concrete girder, exhibit larger vibration under traffic. Engineer should also be alert for any resonance that may be felt during passage of trains. Check members for cleanliness and freedom from debris. Unclean members should be especially s Members subjected to compressive forces are prone to distortion and buckling. Most compression members can bendtwist which can reduce their effectiveness significantly. Cleaning may be necessary to properly inspect the members for cracks and corrosion. Joints with HSFG bolts are designed to transfer the forces through friction between the contact surfaces of the connected members and plates. If the force on the joint exceeds the service loads, the joints can slip. Slip of the joint may indicate that the loads have, sometimes in the past, exceeded the serviceability stage limit. Apping the bolt with a hammer is not allowed.  defects in steel material of construction may be visible anywhere in the girder and these should all be recorded with specific location of each defect pinpointed. Given below is a list of locations which are more critical and the chances of finding defects at such places is higher than other locations. Open web girders are not provided with ballasted deck and given their longer spans, adequate and safe access and walkways are crucial to facilitate effective inspection and maintenance. All walkways, footpaths, railings, ladders and access to trolleymam refuges should be examined as a part of inspection. Camber is provided in the girder to compensate for deflection under load. Camber should be retained during service life of the girders if there is no distress. Any loss of camber should be investigated and brought on record. Local buckling indicates overstress of compression members. Wrinkling in the flange, webs or cover plates are common signs of buckling. Defect in the steel material of construction may be visible anywhere in the girder. The track structure represents interface between the bridge and the live load. Strictly speaking, the track structure is a part of track inspection and maintenance. The behavior of the track on the bridge is different from that on the embankment and therefore deserves to be separated from routine track inspection. Details of the treatment of LWR over the bridge should be carefully studied so that relevant features of the same can be properly inspected. Any kink in the alignment of the track especially over a pier suggests some abnormal situation related to that pier. The level of track provides the earliest warning sign about settlement in any of the foundations or any other distress like tilt or shift. LWR may or may not have been continued over the bridge depending upon its overall length, rail section used and the temperature zone in which it falls. Detailed level measurements may be recorded if there are visual signs of disturbance in the track levels. The condition of the ballast wall should be checked for at least up to 50 meters on the 86 Pageapproaches. This portion of the track should be well anchored. The gauge, cross level and packing under the sleepers should also be checked. As many sleeper seats as possible should be closely inspected to get an idea of the general condition of the trackgirder interface. Corrosion in sleepers, local damage to any sleeper and condition of welds should be inspected. Condition of guard rail and its fastening should also be checked. Inspection of ancillary structures is important from this perspective. It should be checked whether the footpath provides safe and uninterrupted surface. Inspection of Bridge Ancillaries 7.0 does not by themselves affect the safetystability of the bridge. Ladders are provided to allow access form the track to the top of the pier cap. The integrity of the hand railing should be checked. Trolleyman refuges are provided for parking of inspection trollies or for standing during passage of trains. Connection of the trolleyman refuge structure to the main bridge should be examined carefully for its integrity. Defects in the material of construction concrete or steel should be checked as per the respective guideline for concrete and steel. iance with the applicable DFCCIL Schedule of Dimensions. Inspect the bracket suspenders of pipelinecable support as structural elements. Inspect these for distortion, corrosion and integrity of bolts etc. A pipeline that carries any hazardous material poses a risk of fire and explosion. The integrity of the height gauge should be observed and recorded. gauges are provided to prevent the road vehicles carrying over dimensioned consignment ODC damaging the soffit of the girders. A RCC BoxPipe is typically embedded so as to be surrounded by soil of the embankment. The items to be inspected in a RCc boxpipe are detailed below. The most commonly noticed defect in a RCC BoxPipe is the settlement of a part of it resulting in disturbance to the slopelevelvertical alignment. Unless designed as a siphon, the RCC BoxPipe should have adequate clearance to allow flow of water. Signs of HFL should be looked for to assess if design clearance is available. Inspect the wing face wall for its alignmentverticality and signs of undermining. Check for integrity of the flooring on the approach to the RCC BoxPipe bridges. Rebar corrosion e. Damaged broken edges f. Blisters or pop outs g. Surface abrasion dusting. Cracks in concrete are amongst the most common defect and some of these can be very serious. Delamination or spalling of concrete represent an advanced stage of corrosion of reinforcement. If the defect is located at a structurally critical location, do not aggravate the problem by further taping the concrete. Delamination and spalling are invariably accompanied by visible cracks in the concrete neararound it. Efflorescence is the presence of salt on the concrete surface, often at the cracks. It is a sign of passage of water through the concrete and leaching out of lime.  corrosion of rebar will be generally accompanied by cracks in concrete. Efflorescence, if noticed along with a crack will get covered by item aviii above. If noticed without a crack, its location and size should be noted down. A cold joint or a poorly located and formed construction joint creates a plane of weakness in the concrete element. Bug holes are small air voids visible on the surface of concrete. These can vary from less than a mm in size to as large as 20-25 mm. Large bug holes if too many in number and located at a critical position can result in a serious defect. The location and subjective assessment of size of the larger bug holes may be recorded. edge of concrete element could be damaged at the time or removal of the formwork or during construction and erection of other elements. The severity of the defect will depend on its location and depth of damage. Less cover to rebar is not visible after all concrete has been cast. In some case, such as underside of slabs and beams, impression of reinforcement can be seen indicating very low cover. If such parts are accessible, these should be inspected from touching distance. Blister and pop outs are very local defects and indicated by an irregular cavity on the concrete surface. Not all defects are serious in nature. Some defects are created at the time of construction itself and continue to remain in the absence of repairs. Proper drainage is important to reduce the risk of corrosion. Members and connections subject to high stress fluctuations and stress reversals in service are the most common suspect. Paint is the main defence against corrosion of steel structures. Condition of paint and extent of corrosion are two sides of the same coin. If the paint is free of defect, corrosion is unlikely. However, some cases, corrosion initiated from a small scratch can lead to wider loss of paint protection. Loss of adhesion peeling refers to complete loss of bond between the paint and the substrate. In aggressive environments, this can soon initiate widespread corrosion of the steel. Localised damage scratch is either a construction stage defect caused by damage to paint during transportation and launching which was not touched up. From the CRNs for different components of a bridge, an overall Rating Number ORN for the bridge is then given. The ORN is the lowest of the seven CRNs of abridge, except 0. The aim of creating an objective assessment cannot be met unless there is uniformity in assigning CRN to various elements of the bridge. Assigning a CRN depends on the experience and judgment of the inspecting official. A guideline is required which shall be reviewed from time to time and improved with experience.
